id: Ka Mua, Ka Muri: an Introduction-Wellington Museum, 3 Jervois Quay, Queens Wharf, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Ka Mua, Ka Muri: an Introduction
venue: Wellington Museum, 3 Jervois Quay, Queens Wharf, Wellington
description:
Nau mai, haere mai, we are proud to present the Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum Legal Series, an informative lecture series about the purpose, historical significance and ongoing mahi of The Waitangi Tribunal held alongside the exhibition He Kura Toi Tangata: 50 Years of the Waitangi Tribunal, 1975-2025.

In order to understand our future, we must first understand our past. Therefore, we announce with great pleasure that noted historian Dame Claudia Orange DNZM OBE CRSNZ will present our opening lecture in this series, which focuses on the history of Te Tiriti o Waitangi and the Waitangi Tribunal.

Encouraging discussion on the Treaty of Waitangi is a vital part of continuing efforts to fulfil the promise of the 1840 agreement. Dame Claudia argues that a broad public understanding of the changes that have occurred in the Māori–Crown relationship is essential in order for those relationships to grow. She says that an understanding of history is vital, and informed vigilance is necessary.

Tickets are $35 per session, or $25 for students and SuperGold Card holders, and include one drink and light kai. Doors open 5:30pm. The exhibition He Kura Toi Tangata: 50 Years of The Waitangi Tribunal will remain open to view until 8pm.

Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum

Wednesday 6 August | 6pm – 8pm

Tickets $25–$35 | Book tickets: https://bit.ly/4lgFb0F

id: Bloody Minded: An Evening with Susie Ferguson-The Offering, 65 Main St, Greytown-Event Finder
name: Bloody Minded: An Evening with Susie Ferguson
venue: The Offering, 65 Main St, Greytown
description:
Presented by Featherston Booktown, in association with Mrs Blackwell's Village Bookshop, as part of the Greytown Festival of Christmas.

Join Susie Ferguson, journalist and host of Saturday Morning on RNZ, for a discussion about her life and memoir, 'Bloody Minded', with moderator, Christine Kernohan.

Early in her career, Susie was a war correspondent, the only woman among hundreds of soldiers. She was often one of the boys, hidden behind a flak jacket. Yet, beneath her tough exterior, she was battling excruciating pain from endometriosis, taking 15 painkillers a day to cope with the burning and stabbing sensations in her uterus. But Susie’s story is more than just physical pain—it's about surviving the harsh realities that many women face, including misogyny, discrimination, and the often dismissive attitudes of a healthcare system ill-equipped to address women's needs.

Don't miss this opportunity to hear from one of New Zealand's most respected journalists discuss the importance of resilience, self-advocacy, and finding the courage to share our stories.
Mrs Blackwell’s Village Bookshop will be selling copies of 'Bloody Minded' on the night and Susie will sign your copies after the event.

id: Astronomy On Tap-Space Place at Carter Observatory, 40 Salamanca Rd, Kelburn, Wellington-Event Finder

Since the dawn of time, humanity has gazed at the stars with wonder and curiosity. In this session, we’ll journey through the incredible history and future of space exploration, uncovering how spacecraft, rovers, and telescopes have expanded our understanding of the cosmos and what mysteries still await discovery.

Upon arrival, receive a drink and your first-class inflight snacks. Then sit back and relax in our digital full-dome planetarium as we explore the night sky. Complete your trip through the galaxy with the cash bar and a look through interactive exhibitions.

Whether you’re accompanied by a special someone, a friend, or embarking on a solo adventure, raise your glass to the stars and enjoy the stellar ride.

id: Night Photography: In the Dark-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Night Photography: In the Dark
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Night photography is, by its nature, magical. In the photographer’s hands, the camera becomes a magic box that allows the night to be caught in a way the human eye could never see.

This course gives you the opportunity to explore and sharpen both your technical and creative skills, so you have the ability and vision to capture the enchanting world that resides in the darkness.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
- Identify the equipment needed to make photographs at night
- Identify how to use technical photographic tools in a nighttime context
- Explore techniques that allow you to develop a more creative approach to picture-making including: light painting, intentional camera movement, light trails and working with water and reflections in your images
- Recognise the importance of light and colour in night photography and develop your ability to use it to make dynamic images

You must bring a tripod and, if you have one, a neutral density filter and cable release remote. You need a fully manual DSLR or mirrorless camera and an intermediate understanding of camera functions. Not suitable for point and shoot cameras.


8 weeks, 7:30 PM -9:30PM
Wellington High School
Presented by David Jensen
$159 incl. GST

id: Whakataua: an Adornment Workshop With Neke Moa-The Dowse Art Museum, 45 Laings Rd, Lower Hutt-Event Finder
name: Whakataua: an Adornment Workshop With Neke Moa
venue: The Dowse Art Museum, 45 Laings Rd, Lower Hutt
description:
Create an adornment out of shells, fibre and other natural materials, with the guidance of Pōhatu Roa artist Neke Moa. Bring in any treasures that you’ve foraged – shells, sticks, stones – and create a wearable artwork out of them. Some shells and fibre will be supplied. There are a limited number of spaces available for this workshop, so make sure you register to guarantee your place.

Neke Moa (Ngāti Kahungunu ki Ahuriri, Kai Tahu, Ngāti Porou, Ngāti Tūwharetoa) is an adornment and object artist, predominantly working with Pounamu (NZ jade). In 2000 she gained a Diploma of Design and Art at Te Waananga-o-Raukawa and then furthered her studies at Whitireia NZ, completing a Bachelor of Applied Arts in 2007. Moa has exhibited widely throughout Aotearoa and internationally. Over the last 4 years Moa has taught shell craft in Fiji and Tonga and continues to teach and learn as part of her art practice.

id: The Racket Lounge: Prelude-Bedlam and Squalor, Upstairs, 18 Garrett Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Event Finder
name: The Racket Lounge: Prelude
venue: Bedlam and Squalor, Upstairs, 18 Garrett Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Grab a spot on our couch and enjoy the noise at The Racket Lounge, a chill classical music series featuring up-and-coming Pōneke classical and jazz musicians.

Last year the NZSQ Trust launched the Racket Lounge, a concert series for classical and jazz musicians with experience ranging from students to pros to freely express their creativity in a non-traditional concert setting. It was a huge success, with over 250 audience members and 52 artists over our four sessions. Audiences were raving about the musical variety and great talent they found at the Racket Lounge, and as one audience member commented; “Well done…do it again!” So, we listened, and the Racket Lounge is back for round two! Once again hosted at Bedlam & Squalor (above the Rogue & Vagabond), we welcome audiences, composers and performers back for another four concerts full of innovative, fun, and chill music. From classical to pop covers, video game soundtracks to original compositions, there's something for everyone to sink their teeth into at The Racket Lounge!

Even if you've never been to a classical music concert before, this one is for you. With a 'Choose your price' model you can afford to give it a go - and you might even find something you like!

A Flexible Price, So You Can Take A Chance on Something New:
Our prices range from $5 to $100, just pick the ticket price you feel like paying. At The Racket Lounge, we believe everyone should have access to high-quality but affordable art. If you're a bit strapped for cash right now, but still want a good night out, no worries! Just book yourself a $5 ticket! If you can afford to pay a little more and want to do some good for your community, then pick one of our higher ticket prices and rest assured that your dollars are going towards funding great, accessible art in your city.

All proceeds from ticket sales will go directly into presenting the next Racket Lounge, including paying musicians and artists, hiring instruments and marketing costs. Plus, by choosing a higher price point, you're ensuring that we're able to continue to offer tickets at a lower price point for those who need it.

Please note: Bedlam & Squalor is a licenced venue, so under 18s must be accompanied by a parent or legal guardian. Everyone must bring ID.

id: Conservation Kōrero: Talk Toitoi To Me-ZEALANDIA Eco-Sanctuary, Waiapu Road, Karori, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Conservation Kōrero: Talk Toitoi To Me
venue: ZEALANDIA Eco-Sanctuary, Waiapu Road, Karori, Wellington
description:
They may be little fish in a big pond, but their growing impact has been sending ripples across Zealandia Te Māra a Tāne.

Toitoi, or common bully, have been translocated across three years from Kohangapiripiri near the Pencarrow Lighthouse to the Roto Māhanga/Upper Reservoir in Zealandia. An endearing little ika, these fish are now thriving at Zealandia, being spotted along Te Māhanga stream, in Roto Kawau/Lower Reservoir, and downstream beyond the fence!

Central to the kaupapa of this project was ongoing improvements to translocating the fish as we worked with mana whenua to incorporate traditional mātauranga Māori methods, and now together we want to share the whole story with you.

Join us for our next Conservation Kōrero, where a panel of participants in the toitoi translocations from 2023-2025 share the development of the translocations and the discoveries we made along the way.

This event will be held in the Pāteke Room in the Visitor Centre with light refreshments provided. Doors open at 5.45pm, parking is available at both our Visitor Centre and overflow parking area on Birdwood Street.

In this engaging and informative course, you will unpack the subject of Mental Health, covering topics such as Mental Distress, Mental Disorders, Stress Reactions, and How to Support Someone.

You will also have the opportunity to reflect on your own stress management, wellbeing and resilience.

- By the end of the day, you will have a solid understanding of:- mental health and common mental health disorders,
- gained confidence to be able to have courageous conversations with people you are concerned about and recognise your own wellbeing and gain tools to manage stress

A condition of enrolment is that you must provide photo ID when you attend.

id: Writers on Mondays: Making and Mending-Te Marae, Te Papa Tongarewa, 55 Cable Street, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Writers on Mondays: Making and Mending
venue: Te Marae, Te Papa Tongarewa, 55 Cable Street, Wellington
description:
MAKING AND MENDING: CADENCE CHUNG, GREGORY KAN, JIAQIAO LIU, AND NINA MINGYA POWLES
A poet’s toolbox is filled with techniques to help them kick-start or rebuild a poem, but sometimes the tried and true tricks aren’t enough. How can poets engage with other forms of art and artmaking to challenge and reinvent how poetry is written? New Zealand Poet Laureate Chris Tse talks with Cadence Chung (Mad Diva), Gregory Kan (Clay Eaters), Jiaqiao Liu (Dear Alter), and Nina Mingya Powles (In the Hollow of the Wave) about how their creative pursuits and interests outside poetry shape and inform their latest collections.

Writers on Mondays is presented with the Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa, Circa Theatre and Phantom Billstickers National Poetry Day, and is supported by the Letteri Family.

venue: Greytown Town Hall, 89 Main St, Greytown
description:
Step Inside: Greytown’s Inaugural Mid-Winter Christmas House Tour

This winter, step inside eight handpicked Greytown homes, each beautifully styled and transformed with festive flair for the first-ever Mid-Winter House Tour. From traditional charm to contemporary chic, explore the main living spaces of these inspiring homes and discover how their owners bring the magic of Christmas indoors.

Wander through spaces warmed by crackling fires, admire exquisite table settings, and take in thoughtful, seasonal touches that are sure to spark ideas for your own winter celebrations. Whether you're a design lover, a Christmas enthusiast, or simply looking for a little mid-year magic, this is an event not to miss.

Tickets $75 plus fees

Go VIP for the Ultimate Experience – Tickets $145 plus fees
Upgrade to a VIP ticket and unlock two exclusive experiences:

Rototāwai Tour
Visit Rototāwai, a privately owned homestead on the outskirts of Greytown. This lovingly restored historic home features a unique landscape and an impressive private art collection. A rare chance to view an iconic home not usually open to the public.
Please select your preferred time for the homestead visit: 10am or 12pm.

Exclusive Wine Tasting at Alexia Urban Winery
Recently named one of The Real Review's Top 10 Wineries of 2025, Alexia is leading the way in innovation while celebrating its winemaking heritage. Enjoy an intimate tasting hosted by acclaimed winemaker Jane Cooper, and sample a selection of fresh, distinctive wines, including Gamay, Chenin Blanc and Grüner Veltliner.

Please select your preferred time for the wine tasting: 3pm or 4pm.

Programme for the day:
9am - 10am: Collect your shoe bag and programme from the Greytown Town Hall, and find out where you'll be starting your self-drive tour.
10am: Go to your first allocated home, then make your way around the remaining homes in the order and pace that you wish. Feel free to stop for coffee or a bite to eat, or some shopping on the way!
Note: VIP ticket holders need to be at Rototāwai and Alexia at their allocated times (as selected when you purchase your ticket)
4pm: Tour finishes, feel free to make your way back into Greytown to enjoy the Wairarapa Festival of Christmas festivities

This is a self-drive, self-paced tour. Proudly supported by Dave and Jennah of Property Brokers , in support of our charity partner, Hospice Wairarapa.

Tickets are strictly limited – don’t miss this mid-winter celebration of style, creativity, and seasonal joy. This event is part of the Wairarapa Festival of Christmas programme. All the details at www.greytownvillage.com

id: Anyone Can Draw - Structural-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Anyone Can Draw - Structural
venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
description:
In this course you will examine structural drawing with a careful helpful approach, focusing on simple perspective drawing and the value of geometric shapes and solids. Both these structural approaches contribute greatly to the success of your drawing.

Geometric shapes can simplifying a subject, unify a drawing and make compositions dynamic. Geometric solids will help render any subject in three dimensions and transition to perspective.

A good working knowledge of the concepts of perspective will help you draw any subject with correct dimensionality. It can also help in your realist drawing, painting and invented subjects and environments. These concepts are also used in most two dimensional art because it enables us to realise great spatial effects, making it an invaluable tool to add to your skill set.

In this course you will learn the following:

- Focus on geometric shapes and solids and how they contribute to both realist and abstract drawing
- Form an appreciation of geometry and shapes that can help with constructing a drawing
- The important tools, methods and concepts of one-point, two-point and three-point perspective
- Universal boxing, drawing ellipses
- Hints in locating helpful lines and axis to draw real subjects
- Introductory methods of working that blend perspective knowledge with real drawing situations

All basic materials supplied.

Wednesday evenings, 6:30 - 8:30 pm, 23 July - 10 September.
OR
Friday mornings, 10 am - 1 pm, 25 July - 12 September.

name: Christmas Carnival Grand Finale - thanks to SWDC
venue: Greytown Town Hall, 89 Main St, Greytown
description:
The action kicks off from 3pm for the Grand Finale of Aotearoa’s happiest mid-winter festival. We’re closing off Main Street so you can wander freely, soak up the last flutterings of snow, explore the Night Markets, and eat, drink, and be merry.
When evening falls, get ready for an unforgettable street party and Carnival parade – Wairarapa style! Watch the performers dance past – or if you're feeling inspired, jump in behind them and get your groove on!

Then, to cap off the month of magic, we’re ending with a bang – fireworks will light up the sky at 7:45pm, launching from the Greytown School grounds, making Main St a perfect viewing spot.

It's also your last chance to take advantage of festival deals and offers at our gorgeous boutique stores, and admire their stunning displays. Many will be open late for evening shopping. If you haven't already, make sure you decorate your Hari pup and hang it proudly on the Greytown Lands Trust Community Christmas Tree! Or head along and admire the children's artwork.

So come and celebrate with us, raise a glass of mulled wine (or a hot chocolate) by one of the open fires or outdoor heaters, and toast the end of the 2025 Festival of Christmas.
And the best part? It’s completely free!

Please Note:
The Wairarapa Festival of Christmas features flashing lights and light projections that may affect those with light sensitivity. We love dogs - especially Hari - but please leave them safe at home during busy times. Please listen carefully to our friendly traffic marshals and stay within the designated safe zones.

id: Ghost Trio-Waikanae Memorial Hall, 7 Pehi Kupa St, Waikanae-Event Finder
name: Ghost Trio
venue: Waikanae Memorial Hall, 7 Pehi Kupa St, Waikanae
description:
Programme

Beethoven: Piano Trio, Opus 70, No 1 "The Ghost"
Takemitsu: Between Tides
Glen Downie: Sonata da chiesa
Shostakovich: Piano Trio No 2, Opus 67


The Ghost Trio will perform in Waikanae as part of a Chamber Music New Zealand tour. Popular New Zealand musicians Monique Lapins (violin), Ken Ichinose (cello) and pianist Gabriela Glapska are all familiar faces on the Waikanae stage, having appeared with numerous other chamber ensembles. They have named their group after the work they are about to perform on this tour - Beethoven's Opus 70, No 2 trio which is known as "The Ghost" because of the eerie, ominous sounds in the gloomy second movement. The two outer movements are much brighter, the first bold and energetic, the third witty and playful.

Two brief and contrasting works complete the first half of this varied concert. Japanese composer Toru Takemitsu has been acclaimed as the most important composer in Japanese musical history. His piece "Between Tides" illustrates his great love of nature. New Zealand composer Glen Downie's new work (being premiered on this tour) was inspired by the simplicity of Vivaldi’s cello sonatas and the baroque form known as sonata da chiesa.

The second half of the concert will be dominated by one of the greatest piano trios of the 20th Century - Shostakovich's Opus 67. Written in 1944 amid World War II, the trio responds to the conflicts of those times, but also to the composer's personal circumstances. It is an elegy for the tragic victims of war, but also expresses Shostakovich's grief at the sudden death of his closest friend and mentor Ivan Ivanovich Sollertinsky. The opening movement is bleak and despairing, followed by a lively, almost obsessive Scherzo. The third movement is a starkly beautiful funeral dirge while the last movement brings together themes from the previous movements, also introducing new Russian and Jewish themes.

Door sales will be available for this concert or tickets can be bought from Waikanae New World and Moby Dickens Books in Paraparaumu Beach. Ticket enquiries can be made at 022 345 5316 or from the society's website www.waikanaemusic.org.nz

The Ghost Trio concert is presented as part of Chamber Music New Zealand’s "In Partnership Series".

What if your to-do list felt as nourishing as your breathwork practice?

This is the perfect 60-minute live workshop where Elebreath®️ meets mindful systems—a space to organize your life and business without slipping into hustle mode. We’ll blend somatic awareness with Notion, the all-in-one tool I use to manage my energy, organize my mind, and create with more ease.

This isn’t just about getting things done. It’s about doing it from a regulated, resourced place—so your nervous system feels held every step of the way.

How your nervous system influences focus, clarity, and creative flow

How I integrate Elebreath®️ to map my energy before taking action

The exact Notion system I use to track tasks, brain dumps, and flow states

How to design a dashboard that moves with your body, not against it

You’ll Walk Away With:

A fully set-up Notion workspace that mirrors your calmest, clearest self

A Daily Flow Tracker + Brain Dump Inbox to release the mental clutter

Tools to show up consistently—even on low-energy days

Included in your ticket:

Lifetime access to the free resources like: guided breathwork, fatigue guide, and many more

Bonus PDF: Nervous-System Safe Productivity Rituals

An amazing plant-based dinner & dessert!

This is productivity with breath, intention, and soul.
Come as you are. Leave with clarity, calm, and a system that works with you.

Meet Lynn, your host

Lynn supports visionaries, wellness practitioners, and purpose-driven creatives to return to their bodies, unlock their energetic potential, and grow businesses that feel deeply aligned and regenerative.

Her approach weaves together somatic healing and conscious entrepreneurship—blending breathwork, trauma-informed nervous system care, yogic wisdom, and energetic mastery into my signature modality, Elebreath®️. It’s more than a method—it’s a remembrance of your most embodied, empowered self.

Alongside this deep inner work, Lynn guides Soulful Notion®️ Workshops—where nervous system regulation meets mindful productivity. Using Notion as a soul-aligned system, we co-create space for structure, ease, and clarity—so you can live and work in a way that honors your energy.

Whether you're seeking deeper purpose, more sustainable flow, or a business that mirrors your dharma—my work is here to support your return to truth, breath by breath.

What are fidget rings? Also known as spinner rings or stim rings, fidget rings have loose bands attached that can move and swivel around - it's interactive sculpture you can wear!

In this course you’ll be lead through the design and creation of custom copper and silver rings, with copper, brass and silver wire spinner bands adding novelty and movement to a classic ring design.

This course offers beginners a fun introduction to jewellery making, and for those with some jewellery experience, it offers a great way to advance and expand your making techniques to new levels.

id: PADI Open Water Diver Course-New Zealand Sea Adventures, 9 Marina View, Porirua - Mana-Event Finder
name: PADI Open Water Diver Course
venue: New Zealand Sea Adventures, 9 Marina View, Porirua - Mana
description:
PADI is by far the largest and most popular Scuba diver certifying system in the world and for good reason. Courses are fun, safe, relevant, and packed with excitement! No matter what country you are in, your PADI qualification will be recognised.

The practical part of your Open Water Scuba Diver course takes just four days! During the first weekend, we make it very easy and convenient for you with our on-site dive pool (the only one in the Wellington Region). Our pool is where you learn to dive, so we can go at your pace, no matter how long it takes. During the first weekend, you learn and practice all the necessary dive skills. Once completed, you will be ready for the sea dives.

Once you are a certified diver, you will receive an eCard on your PADI App showing your qualification – and any PADI Dive Centre will be able to confirm your certification on-line. You will also be qualified to attend the PADI Advanced Open Water Diver course, and our regular Dive Days.

We want to make your diving safe and enjoyable. Welcome to the exciting world of Scuba diving!

If you have any questions please call, email or stop by our Dive Store.

Kind regards,
Tony Howell
PADI Course Director
Tel: 04 233-8238 Email: nzsa@scubadiving.co.nz Web: www.scubadiving.co.nz
9 Marina View, Mana, Porirua 5026


PADI Open Water Diver course at a glance:
•Digital theory: Open Water Diver eLearning Course (allow 8-14 hours)
•Practical: One weekend pool training, one weekend with four sea dives
•Options: One-on-one or unscheduled dates – additional costs apply.
•Start Time: Please be at NZ Sea Adventures by 8.30am daily.

Location:
We are located at 9 Marina View, Mana, Porirua; just north of the Paremata bridge on SH1. Look for the big yellow building. Check our website for location.

Prerequisites:
•Be at least 10 years old (special conditions apply for 10 and 11-year-olds)
•Be able to swim 300m (no time limit) and swim/float for 10 minutes.
•Be medically fit to dive. Check the Diver Medical Participant Questionnaire. If you answer YES to any of the questions or have any doubts, a visit to your doctor is required.
•Elearning must be completed before your pool training can begin.
•Complete the RDP Tables Quiz and Exam if you don’t have a dive computer.

What to Bring:
•Completed Diver Medical Participant Questionnaire.
•If Under 18 years – bring a Parent or Legal Guardian to sign your forms.
•A pen, swimming costume, towel and a snack for the breaks.
•Any personal dive equipment you wish to use.
•The $450.00 balance of your course fee.

Cost:
•Scheduled Open Water Diver Course Fee: total is $750.00; deposit is $300.00.
•Includes: PADI eLearning Course, Dive Gear Rental, Pool Sessions, and Sea Dives. Rental wetsuits are available in stock sizes only. Other sizes are available for purchase. Made-to-measure options can be ordered and purchased
•10% off all in-store purchases during your course. Does not include packages.
•$20 off your course fee for every person you get to sign on with you.

When:
Our PADI Open Water Diver Courses are scheduled year-round. See our online calendar for scheduled course dates or ask in store. Booking early guarantees your place and price.
Looking for different dates or smaller classes? Ask about our one-off course options. Let us know what you need and we will do our best to help (conditions may apply).

Booking your course:
•Course bookings can be made in-store, via email, online or over the phone
•The deposit of $300.00 secures your place on a course and purchases your eLearning course.
•Deposits are transferable to another person but are not refundable.
•Elearning courses, once redeemed, cannot be transferred.
•Before we can send you the eLearning link, we require your full name, date of birth, a valid personal email address and phone number.
•Your course balance is to be paid before we can begin your pool training.

id: Visual Journalling - Drawing for Mindfulness-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Visual Journalling - Drawing for Mindfulness
venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
description:
Learn how to use drawing and mark-making for visual journalling, to draw out your inner guidance and resources, and bring a creative form of wellness into your daily life.

Lara Phillips, a creative facilitator trained in Interactive Drawing Therapy, will guide you through simple practices that open our subconscious; a resource we can all tap into, to help ourselves.

Note, this is not therapy or counselling rather a self-care tool that you can integrate alongside other wellbeing practices, such as journalling, walking or meditation.

No drawing skills required, this is more mark making not art making.

Each week combines a mix of guided drawings (where you follow cues), practices with others in the group, and self-guided drawings, using knowledge and tools you can take away.

Week 1: Ground
Learn what sits at the heart of this practice, and how to access your subconscious to draw out what it is you need.

Week 2: Wonder
Explore techniques with others in the group, to learn the power of open cues and different ways to listen to your inner voice.

Week 3: Play
Experiment with different ways of playing with your drawings, to stimulate the subconscious to guide you.

Week 4: Self
Apply your knowledge from the workshop to develop self-guiding skills to continue drawings at home.

What is provided: All necessary materials are provided. This includes A3 paper and coloured crayons, as well as printed resources with guiding cues.

What to bring: (Optional) Any preferred journalling materials of choice, such as large journals, coloured markers or coloured pencils. Feel free to bring an A3 folder/case/wallet.

Homework will be offered to help integrate the practice with your personal life.


Sundays, 11 am - 1 pm, 20 July - 10 August.

id: Pelvic Power Workshop-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Pelvic Power Workshop
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Pelvic floor muscles become weakened, often after childbirth, and can cause incontinence, constipation or frequent urination. These Feldenkrais Method® techniques will help you regain muscle efficiency and tone. For women only.

Description
Apart from assisting with supporting internal organs, and controlling elimination, the pelvic floor is an important part of a woman's overall stability and posture, so you will gain improvement in this respect as well. You'll learn far more than conventional pelvic floor strengthening.

You'll learn to differentiate different parts of the pelvic floor, and also how the pelvic floor functions in conjunction with breathing and spinal movements.

By the end of the workshop, you’ll be able to:
-Recognise the anatomy of the pelvic floor, where the muscles are and how they work
- Coordinate the pelvic floor muscles with breathing, and with the spine, and recognise its role in overall good posture
- Discover what habits you have which work against your pelvic floor muscles working well
- Practise exercises designed to help you rehabilitate and strengthen your pelvic floor

Please note that instructions are given verbally rather than by demonstration, so good hearing and understanding of English is required. For women only.

The best-kept secret, the Gin Garden Bar, is making its welcome return this July. Join us every Friday and Saturday from 5pm - 8.30pm at The White Swan Garden Bar for another season of festive fun, warming cocktails, and winter delights. Tucked away, this hidden gem is the perfect spot to rug up in your Christmas sweater and woolly hat (spot prizes for award-winning attire!), sip on a Greytown Distilling Company Gin Mulled Gin, and soak in the warm glow of twinkling lights. Grab some delicious food and enjoy the atmosphere.

Live music every Friday and Saturday from 5-8pm will set the scene, while a crackling fire invites you to toast marshmallows and sip on rich hot chocolate. Step right up for another unforgettable season, where the magic of Christmas meets the charm of a winter carnival.

id: The Lunch Society: Winter Warmer-The Wellington Club, Level 4, 88 The Terrace, Wellington-Event Finder
name: The Lunch Society: Winter Warmer
venue: The Wellington Club, Level 4, 88 The Terrace, Wellington
description:
Join us for 'The Lunch Society: Winter Warmer' , an afternoon of delicious food, meaningful connections, and inspiring conversations to warm the soul.

The Lunch Society is a quarterly ladies’ lunch event designed to bring together women in Wellington for networking, entertainment, and philanthropy.

This event is all about bringing together like-minded individuals to connect, learn, and share in a vibrant and welcoming atmosphere. Expect an engaging guest speaker, valuable networking opportunities, and plenty of moments to inspire you.

Settle in for a beautifully curated experience featuring:

• A powerful keynote by Katherine Rich on Breaking Barriers, Building Bridges: Women Shaping New Zealand’s Future
• A delicious two-course set menu and a refreshing welcome drink on arrival
• An exclusive goodie bag for every guest + spot prizes
• A chance to give back, with a portion of all ticket sales donated to Barnardos

Whether you're a returning guest or joining us for the first time, you’ll be welcomed into a warm, inclusive space that celebrates women, ambition, and community. Come to be inspired, stay to be part of something bigger.

id: Spanish Language Classes - Introductory 2-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Spanish Language Classes - Introductory 2
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
For those who have done Spanish Introductory 1 (16 hours) or have equivalent knowledge (e.g. who may have picked up some basic survival language through travel).

Outcomes:
By the end of the course, you'll:
- Have an improved understanding of, and ability to use more successfully, the material from the previous course
- Have some improved ability to express yourself in basic Spanish
- Have some understanding of present tense irregular verbs, and be able to use some of them correctly
- Understand how comparisons are formed and be able, with some success, to use them correctly
- Have some understanding of how pronouns work, and be able, on some occasions, to use them correctly
- Be able to use, successfully at times, the Spanish for this, that, these and those

8 weeks, Wed 7:30 PM – 9:30 PM
Wellington High School
Presented by Tony Ilott
$199. incl. GST

id: Raising Great Kids In An Overindulgent World-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Raising Great Kids In An Overindulgent World
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Parenting today delivers unprecedented challenges – are you wondering what went wrong and somehow ended up living with a child you don’t recognise as should be belonging to you? Get a new perspective, an easy-to-understand model to follow and tools to help you to raise likeable and respectful children in an age of over-indulgence.

This workshop will be a confronting one that will expose you to the risks that children face in this modern overindulgent world. Many have become used to being the constant centre of attention and are unable to delay gratification and aren’t competent in everyday skills.

They have few self-care skills and skills relating to others, can’t take personal responsibility and don’t know what is enough or what is “normal” for others – these children end up having a difficult time of it in life and you will too.

You’ll take away new insight and knowledge plus strategies that you can apply that very night to help your child to be a responsible, likeable and respectful person.

By the end of the session, you’ll be able to:
- Reflect on the current context parents are faced with today
- Find the relevant research
- Practise the parenting tools and discuss the model
- Know where to go to get support

Aimed at parents, grandparents and caregivers of children of all ages.

Presented by Madeleine Taylor.

Join us for a special mid-winter evening as the Wairarapa Wine Region comes to Wellington. This exclusive event offers you the chance to meet the winemakers and experience the region’s finest wines — all without leaving the capital.

Unwind after work and enjoy our Urban Cellar Door experience with colleagues, friends, or a partner. You’ll have the opportunity to sample wines from up to 15 outstanding Wairarapa wineries, accompanied by a selection of delicious canapés designed to complement each drop.

id: Monthly Jazz Night: Les Tripes- Parisian Swing Trio-The Thistle Inn, 3 Mulgrave St, Thorndon, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Monthly Jazz Night: Les Tripes- Parisian Swing Trio
venue: The Thistle Inn, 3 Mulgrave St, Thorndon, Wellington
description:
Get ready for a night of irresistible rhythm and sizzling jazz!

Swing clarinetist Oscar Lavën, guitarist Adrian Jensen, and double-bass raconteur Robert Henderson are "Les Tripes" (french for "The Guts") ; a hard-working interpretation of the irresistibly heart-pumping film-noir sound of Django Reinhardt's Quintette du Hot Club de France. Lavën, Jensen and Henderson are professional musicians based in Wellington, and have honed their project through years of performance in venues large and small.

Les Tripes will have you tapping your feet and swinging along as they infuse each performance with passion, precision, and a touch of French flair.

Don’t miss the chance to experience a night of pure, swinging magic!

id: Tuesday Jewellery-Making in 8 Weeks-Workspace Studios Ltd, 65 Abel Smith St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Tuesday Jewellery-Making in 8 Weeks
venue: Workspace Studios Ltd, 65 Abel Smith St, Wellington
description:
Our popular weeknight classes are the best way for beginners to get into jewellery making in a lively, warm and friendly environment. It starts on Tue 12 August and runs for 8 weeks until Tue 30 September, 5.30-8pm.

Beginners will focus on cabochon stone set ring. The stone setting process teaches you many fundamental techniques in one project!

We start with basic ring making in copper or brass, students will learn measuring, texturing, shaping, cutting and soldering.
Then we move on to making a practice ring set with a cabochon stone (cabochon means it has a flat bottom and a smooth domed top).

Once your first setting is completed you can move to working in silver and produce another stone set ring with more interesting design elements.

Advanced: Chain Making and other projects.

Please see the link on the Regular Classes page for more detail on course content.

Included in the class fee are copper and brass for practising on, up to 8 grams of sterling silver, an extra $8 for stones and fine silver and all consumables such as sandpaper, solder and chemicals. Extra metals and materials are available for purchase in the studio.

id: Pocket Shrine Workshop-Wellington Museum, 3 Jervois Quay, Queens Wharf, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Pocket Shrine Workshop
venue: Wellington Museum, 3 Jervois Quay, Queens Wharf, Wellington
description:
Join us for a relaxed, drop-in style workshop where you’ll craft your own pocket shrine. These miniature altars are made inside small tins and can be dedicated to someone or something meaningful to you. It could be in memory of a loved one, in honour of a favourite artist, pet, place, or even a whimsical nod to the faeries. Anything goes.

Pocket shrines are designed to be carried with you or kept close. You might keep yours on your desk, in your bag, or tucked in your pocket to bring comfort, inspiration, or connection wherever you go.

We’ll have everything you need to bring your shrine to life, including collage materials, fabric scraps, buttons, beads, and more. If you’d like to make a shrine in memory of someone special, you are welcome to bring a small photo of them to include.

This event is part of Takurua Hauora: Winter Wellness, a Wellington event series promoting health and wellbeing inspired by Sir Mason Durie’s Whare Tapa Whā model.

Suitable for ages 12+.

Saturday 2 August | 2pm–4pm | $15 per person | Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum

id: The Crown Picture Theatre-The Crown Picture Theatre, 79 Main Street, Greytown-Event Finder
name: The Crown Picture Theatre
venue: The Crown Picture Theatre, 79 Main Street, Greytown
description:
Greytown’s Picture Theatre returns to show some Hollywood classics!

Opening for a short pop-up season this July, The Crown returns as Greytown’s boutique picture theatre. With a cosy 40 seats per screening and the very latest big screen and sound technology supplied by the wonderful team at Newbolds 100% Masterton, get ready to relive some classic films at special 4pm screenings during the Festival. You’ll also be able to enjoy a delightful range of snacks and beverages during your entertainment experience.

79 Main Street, Greytown was the original location of Greytown’s first picture theatre and we are bringing this tribute pop-up version to the village once more. Head down the driveway north of Verandah to find The Crown and book online for our special Festival season now. It’s going to be a sellout.

Choose from a range of romantic classics sponsored by Mrs Blackwell’s Village Bookshop or immerse yourself in the 1970s and 80s with Mr Blackwell’s Childhood Heroes. Add some musicals and you’ve got a dose of picture theatre nostalgia and the chance to see these films on the giant Crown screen, thanks to Newbolds 100%.

id: The Carol Bean Band-Hilltop, 17 Upland Road, Kelburn, Wellington-Event Finder
name: The Carol Bean Band
venue: Hilltop, 17 Upland Road, Kelburn, Wellington
description:
Gate opens 6.30pm Music Starts 7pm Saturday 9 August 2025
The Carol Bean Band play a mix of jazzy blues with a heavy helping of original songs and stylish instrumentation.  Carol Bean – vocals and guitar, Costa Botes – guitar(s), George Packard – upright bass, and Andrew Grayson – drums. 
English-born, California-raised, Carol was influenced by the West Coast music of the 60s and the blues of Mississippi John Hurt, Mance Lipscomb, Lightnin’ Hopkins, and Doc Watson. At LA’s Ash Grove and McCabe’s Music Store she was taught her picking style from a young Ry Cooder who encouraged her to buy the Martin guitar she still plays today. Carol has fronted several bands in New Zealand and recorded 3 studio albums, all on Spotify. She continues to perform at the Wellington Roomfulla Blues Club and with the Kelburn Viaduct Municipal Ensemble Jug Band.
"Carol’s singing is versatile, vibrant, and delivers an earthy quality to her songs." Tom Villano, LA
"… when the mood drops she reveals a more intimate, reflective side…." Graham Reid
"The first three songs of Next Bus Out perfectly set the album up for the interesting  journey that is to come." Nick Bollinger.
Costa is a veteran independent filmmaker with several award winning short films and feature length documentaries to his credit, including the notorious ‘mock doc’ Forgotten Silver, which he made with Peter Jackson. For the last two decades he has created a run of films celebrating individuals who are quirky, creative, passionate, and above all, persistent (Struggle No More, The Last Dogs of Winter, Act of Kindness, Angie, When The Cows Come Home).  These films have included studies of musicians (Paddy Burgin's Wooden Box Band, Nigel Gavin’s Circus, and The Shot Band/ Hobnails @ The Paramount Theatre) because Costa has been a persistent closet musician himself. He has had stints with Chris and Eva Prowse, and Carol Bean's Mount Misery String Band. When he was younger, Costa wanted to move his fingers really fast. Now he just tries to put them in the right place, song by song, and man - does he ever. “Tasty”, “Amazing”, “Great playing”.
See Costa Botes | NZ On Screen & Costa Botes Lone Pine Films (vimeo.com)
George is a professional musician and tutor on Whitireia Polytechnic’s Music Programme, trained classically on the cello. George’s first improvisational experiences were playing ukulele along with the Rolling Stones, John Mayall and The Band (in his bedroom).  With little market for improvisational ukulele he took up the double bass.
George enjoys playing in bands that push the envelope and give expression to the human soul. He has played extensively in many Wellington groups (including currently with the Rag Poets band), appearing a number of times for the Wellington International Festival of the Arts, undertaking national tours for Chamber Music New Zealand, and backing overseas artists in New Zealand. His playing ranges from classical to jazz, to Latin, to ethnic fusion to Americana and country. He believes - at a fundamental level - that music is about human beings making sense of the world and themselves, and about helping heal the world.
Andrew is also the drummer for the band Ghostplane (Beneath the Sleepy Lagoon; Panther Valley Country Club (Arch Hill Records), which includes Phoenix Foundation members). Not only has he joined our team, but his passion is surfing - so let's say he's the youngest and the fittest.
Not for profit, supporting our dedicated musicians. Suggested donation $30
Come along and enjoy this gig in our special space, up close and personal.
Teas, Coffee and Snacks provided. You're welcome to bring anything you'd like to eat or drink.
Parking available in the Coupon zones of Upland Rd & Glasgow St free after 6pm weekdays, and free all through the weekends. The Wilson Carpark at the top of the Cable Car charges 24/7.

id: Elton John vs Billy Joel *NZ Tribute*-Copthorne Hotel & Resort Solway Park, 246 High St, Solway, Masterton-Event Finder
name: Elton John vs Billy Joel *NZ Tribute*
venue: Copthorne Hotel & Resort Solway Park, 246 High St, Solway, Masterton
description:
NZ’s Award-winning hit tribute show “Elton John vs. Billy Joel” are coming to Solway Masterton as part of their NZ-WIDE TOUR!

Doors 7pm , show starts 7.30pm sharp

After wildly successful sell-out shows across New Zealand, join Cam and Sam for an intimate night out as they wow audiences both young and old performing the greatest hits of Elton John and Billy Joel LIVE! Piano Man, Rocket Man, Uptown Girl, Goodbye Yellow Brick Road, We didn’t start the fire, Bennie and the Jets, She’s always a woman, Crocodile Rock and many many more.

Your favourite Elton and Billy songs are in safe hands with Cam and Sam, these professional touring NZ musicians have performed on live national television, commercial radio and featured in the NZ Music Charts in careers spanning two decades. This amazing Piano Man extravaganza features astonishing costumes, two grand pianos in black and white, a lighting show plus plenty of banter and all the songs you love.

Let's face it, Elton John and Billy Joel require little introduction, their music has provided a soundtrack for generations of loving fans. Englishman Sir Elton John has sold over 300 million records, making him one of the best-selling music artists of all time. He has more than fifty Top 40 hits on the UK Singles Chart and US Billboard Hot 100, including seven number-ones in the UK and nine in the US, as well as seven consecutive number-one albums in the US.

American Billy Joel has sold more than 150 million records and ranks as one of the most popular recording artists and respected entertainers in the world. Joel has had 33 Top 40 hits and 23 Grammy nominations. In 1999 he was inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame and has received the Recording Industry Association of America Diamond Award, presented for albums that have sold over 10 million copies.

id: Pataka Friends Winter Music Series-PATAKA Art + Museum, Cnr Parumoana and Norrie St, Porirua - Mana-Event Finder
name: Pataka Friends Winter Music Series

description:

Performers are:
Sun 20 July: Papaioea Piano Trio: classical concert. Guy Donaldson (piano), Elizabeth Patchett (violin) and Robert Ibell (cello), present a beautiful programme of music including Beethoven’s ‘Ghost trio’.

Sun 27 July: Kevin & Fran: Fran Barton and pianist Kevin Clark present a melange of music from jazz to pop to razzmatazz, humour and everything in between.

Sun 3 August: Hobnail: Hobnail have played for 30 years, making toes tap, feet dance and hearts soar with their blend of Celtic, folk, country and rock.

Sun 10 August: Mana College Y11 NCEA Music students: a vocal duo singing a variety of duets and solos; and a drum and guitar duo performing various light rock and pop songs.

id: Ngā Tūrua Kiwi Play Space for Under 5s-Capital E, 4 Queens Wharf, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Ngā Tūrua Kiwi Play Space for Under 5s
venue: Capital E, 4 Queens Wharf, Wellington
description:
Sniff, scratch and burrow at Ngā Turua Kiwi, Kiwi Burrows.

In our latest play activation, whānau can explore themes of creating homes, a connection to whenua, and the importance of conservation in Pōneke.

Imagine yourself as a Western Brown Kiwi as you:
- Wriggle and crawl through kiwi burrows of different shapes and sizes.
- Discover hidden surprises on the forest floor, including crunchy textures, a bouncy seat, and even pests hiding amongst the leaf litter.
- Climb the towering tree to the top of the forest canopy, then slide all the way down to the forest floor.
- Get creative and build your own cozy tūrua burrow using ‘raw’ materials (wheelchair-accessible).

There will be something for every age and accessibility-level, with both high-energy and low-energy play options, a pēpē baby area, and wheelchair-accessible play stations.

This activation is supported by Capital Kiwi Project.

PlayHQ is Nōku te Ao Capital E’s public indoor play space for tamariki aged 0-5.

Open Monday-Saturday, 9.30am-3.30pm.

Ngā Tūrua Kiwi will be our final PlayHQ activation at Queens Wharf, before we move to Te Matapihi ki te Ao Nui, the new Central Library.

Nōku te Ao Capital E is located at 4 Queens Wharf, Wellington. No bookings required, donations appreciated.

id: Ngaio Repair Cafe-Ngaio Union Church, 3 Kenya St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Ngaio Repair Cafe
venue: Ngaio Union Church, 3 Kenya St, Wellington
description: Ngaio Repair Café, organised in and by Ngaio Union Church, is part of the worldwide Repair Café movement to cut down waste and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Our local volunteer repairers will look at and try to fix all sorts of household gear: wooden, metal, electrical, electronic, pottery, computer, fabric, toys, clothing, beads, cardboard – as long as it’s small enough for you to bring. One of our volunteers is a guitar repairer who can mend and tune any fretted instruments. Another has an oilstone and will sharpen knives. While you wait to have your item looked at, tea and coffee and cold drink are provided. Children with care-givers are welcome. We have some basic materials on site but if your broken thing needs specific parts (e.g. zip, plug) please bring those along. It’s all free but a gold coin koha is appreciated to help local community need. We open each third Saturday of the month beginning March and finishing November.

id: Build your very own Terrarium!-Foliage et al, 2 Hastwell Street, Greytown-Event Finder
name: Build your very own Terrarium!
venue: Foliage et al, 2 Hastwell Street, Greytown

Whether it's for your bookshelf, table or cabinet, your personalised terrarium will add a touch of greenery and elegance to any space. Everything you need to create your masterpiece will be provided, from the container to the soil, plants, and decorative elements, we've got you covered.

No prior experience is necessary, our expert instructors will guide you through each step, ensuring you leave with a beautifully crafted terrarium and newfound skills to continue your botanical adventures.

id: Te Reo Māori - Introductory 1-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Te Reo Māori - Introductory 1
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
This course is for beginners who have no prior knowledge of te reo Māori or Māori culture. (NZ Citizens and residents pay $109 with ID, all others pay $199).

Description
Te Reo Māori - Introductory 1

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:

• Have a basic understanding of the Māori spiritual and natural worlds (mana atua, mana whenua), and our important connections to them
• Identify the sounds of Māori letters and pronounce letter combinations using correct intonation and stress patterns
• Confidently greet people, introduce yourself and communicate basic personal information in an informal context
• Identify and respond to phrases in the classroom including basic commands/instructions
• Confidently describe the day/date, time, and the weather

NOTE: This course is subsidised with funding from the Tertiary Education Commission (TEC) and you must provide photo ID when you attend your first session, if applicable.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

name: Colourful Torch-Fired Enamels - Taster
venue: Workspace Studios Ltd, 65 Abel Smith St, Wellington
description:

Music from 5pm FREE ENTRY, koha for the band encouraged

id: Diesel Jenny x Synthetic Children-Valhalla, 154 Vivian Street, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Diesel Jenny x Synthetic Children
venue: Valhalla, 154 Vivian Street, Wellington
description:
Two of Aotearoa’s most rungle hardware acts are joining forces for a mid-winter tour across the country this July. Armed with new releases and a reckless lack of MIDI cables, longtime pals Synthetic Children and Diesel Jenny are packing gear into the whip for a trip up and down the motu. The six-date tour will see the pair serve up their respective dishes in Pōneke on Thursday the 17th of July, alongside ethereal favourite Ekho Laliah.

Via hardware synths and drum machines, Synthetic Children (Te Papaioea’s Celina Goacher) is bringing bubbly synths, auto-tuned vulnerabilities, and sub-rattling beats. Her latest Smooch EP, and appearance on the Big Fresh Collective’s Footmahi compilation, show an emerging fun side to her dancefloor arsenal, following the murky weight of 2023’s Everything’s Perpetual. Donnys worldwide have heralded the new release as a “freshly cooked 3 course meal, served up by Palmy’s premier snack pack herself”. Think wonky hyperpop with plenty of low end.

Diesel Jenny’s (Pōneke’s Josh Finegan) live set will blend brain-breaking breaks with sugar-rush synths and 3D club energy years. This tour will celebrate the inaugural release of Diesel Jenny’s white label series with a rock-solid RUC-exempt two-tracker.

With multiple releases on underground mainstays Big Fresh Collective and Bankrupt Records as ABG, this isn’t the first time Diesel Jenny’s revved the engine.

Ekho Laliah is an Aotearoa based artist who stitches together elements of dream pop, freak folk, and ethereal electronica into sonic tapestries with experimental production as the backbone.

Tickets $15 through UTR or $20 at the door

id: Pottery - Handbuilding Basics-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Pottery - Handbuilding Basics
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Learn how to prepare and alter clay. (Held at Wellington Potters' Association, 130 Grant Road, Thorndon).

Learn how to prepare and alter clay: pinch, coil, slab, extruder and roller use. Understand shrinkage and clay care, joining techniques, drape and press moulding, mark making, slip making and application - as well as tetrahedron, cone and cylinder production

The techniques learnt during the making will provide an excellent springboard to creating a wide array of ceramic objects in the future.

The emphasis will be on learning techniques and honing those skills and by the end of the 8 sessions you will have completed three works which will be fired and glazed.

Pottery courses are held at Wellington Potters' Association, 130 Grant Road, Thorndon. All our courses are scheduled up to a year in advance which means the at times we may need to make changes to the original schedule. Please make sure you check your emails regularly in case of any changes.

All materials included in course fee. For more information about Wellington Potters, click on this link.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

id: Writers on Mondays-Te Marae, Te Papa Tongarewa, 55 Cable Street, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Writers on Mondays
venue: Te Marae, Te Papa Tongarewa, 55 Cable Street, Wellington
description:
The poems in Biggs Family Prize in Poetry winner Nafanua Purcell Kersel’s Black Sugarcane can sting and soothe, revealing a paradise despoiled by climate change and colonisation, and celebrating a people resilient in the face of it all. Mikaela Nyman is from the autonomous, demilitarised Åland Islands in Finland. Her first poetry collection in English, Anatomy of Sand, follows on from her climate fiction novel Sado. These two urgent contemporary voices join Tamara Tulitua in a conversation about rising seas, political and personal poetry, the local and global.

Writers on Mondays is presented with the Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa, Circa Theatre and Phantom Billstickers National Poetry Day, and is supported by the Letteri Family.

id: Intro to Watercolour Painting - 8 week course-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Intro to Watercolour Painting - 8 week course
venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
description:
This class is for anyone interested in making realistic watercolour studies of the world around them.

We will be covering the fundamentals of watercolour: washes, edges, colour theory, composition, tonal value, materials, lighting, subtlety and simplification.

Each week there will be a new still life to work from and artist examples to take inspiration from. Students can also bring along items they would like to paint.

No prior painting experience needed.

In this course you will:

- learn all the basics of watercolour painting.
- discover techniques to manage the paint
- build your confidence to start working on your own projects

You will need to purchase your basic materials for this course and bring them to each class. See materials list below.

Material list for this course is as follows:

- Paper: A4 Hahnemühle Brittania Matt 300g Watercolour Paper, 10 sheet pack, or any watercolour paper. (100% cotton cold-pressed best if budget allows).
- Paint: Pebeo Studio Watercolour Paint 12 colour set, or any watercolour paint. [Need these 6 colours: warm red (e.g., cadmium red), cool red (e.g., alizarin crimson), warm yellow (e.g., cadmium yellow), cool yellow (e.g., lemon yellow), warm blue (e.g., ultramarine), cool blue (e.g., cobalt or prussian). Optional colours: raw sienna, burnt sienna, and viridian].
- Brushes: 1 size 12 round synthetic watercolour brush with a fine tip (e.g., Da Vinci Fit Hobby brush round 373/12 is a good option). [Later on, a brush set is useful: large round (size 20 or 30), medium round (size 10 or 12), small round (size 2 or 3), ½ inch flat brush, size 1 rigger brush, & detail brush size 0].
- Also needed expression folding plastic palette or similar
- Masking Tape Delicate 12mm
- A soft pencil (2B or 4B),
- A kneadable eraser

Inverlochy students get a 10% discount from Gordon Harris art supplies shop. Materials can also be purchased from Spotlight, Whitcoulls, Paper Plus, Warehouse Stationery, Takapuna Art Supplies.

Watercolour shown on website - Magnolia in Glass, Mark Adams, 1979

Thursday mornings, 10 am - 1 pm.
24 July - 11 September.

id: Yoga Nidra-Awhi Yoga and Wellbeing Centre, 15 Johnston St., Wellington-Event Finder
name: Yoga Nidra
venue: Awhi Yoga and Wellbeing Centre, 15 Johnston St., Wellington
description:
Join us on the first Friday of every month at to AWHI yourself with a 90-minute Yoga Nidra. Unwind from the stresses of the week and the month in a state of relaxation. Yoga Nidra, often referred to as "yogic sleep," is a deeply restorative practice that promotes physical relaxation, mental clarity, and emotional balance. It's the perfect way to rejuvenate your mind, body, and soul: your hinengaro, tinana and wairua.

Yoga Nidra is a powerful technique that directly works to heal your mind by removing samskaras - untying knots and mental impressions. This practice of learning to relax consciously is well regarded as an antidote for stress, anxiety, poor sleep amongst other health benefits.

What to Expect:
- A 90-minute guided Yoga Nidra Meditation led by one of our experienced instructors
- A comfortable space to lie down (mats, blankets, bolsters & cushions provided)
- A supportive community of fellow meditation enthusiasts
- Complementary herbal tea before/after the session;
- An opportunity to journal your experience, if desired
- A chance to destress and cultivate inner calm

Yoga Nidra is for everyone and no prior experience is required - everyone is welcome to experience the profound benefits of Yoga Nidra with us.

Wear comfortable clothes, and bring an open mind, a journal and eye mask if you have one (not required).

So, mark your calendar for the first Friday of each month and treat yourself to an evening of deep relaxation and mindfulness.

Let's come together and discover the transformative power of Yoga Nidra Meditation. See you there!

id: 123 of Painting - 8 week course-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
name: 123 of Painting - 8 week course
venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
description:
In this introduction to painting, Melissa will start the class on a journey through the basic elements of painting in acrylic and and oil paint. This class is structured for students new to painting as well as returning students from prior 123 of Painting classes or the like.

The class is structured around a series of exercises that explore the foundations of still-life and portrait painting. New students will be informally assessed in order to create a programme that best meets their needs.

With an emphasis on simple beginnings, the lessons will include:

- colour theory
- skin tones, structure and composition
- copying master paintings in order to improve observational skills while learning the components of structure and composition
- students bringing in what they choose to paint and if one is experiencing 'art block', Melissa will have images to paint from

Melissa focuses on a personalised approach for the student with an emphasis on finding that person’s passion in art.

Class is suitable for all levels of experience, we start from where you are.

All basic materials provided.

Monday evenings, 6:30 - 8:30 pm - 21 July - 8 September.
OR
Wednesday evenings, 6:30 - 8:30 pm - 23 July - 10 September.

id: Leadership And Management Part 1-AREA Meetings and Events, 1 O'Reily Ave, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Leadership And Management Part 1
venue: AREA Meetings and Events, 1 O'Reily Ave, Wellington
description:
Learn how to make the transition from buddy to the boss and lead a successful team. Managing staff can be a very rewarding, interesting and fun role, it can also be a tough and demanding job. Between managing your own time and projects, helping your team members solve problems and complete tasks, and helping other managers, your day can fill up before you know it.
This workshop aims to maximise your leadership and management potential and help you become a more confident, effective and efficient leader and manager with information on understanding personality types, effective communication, setting expectations and goals, assigning work, effective delegation, motivating staff, leadership styles, giving feedback and having courageous conversations, understanding what is required to be a good leader and manager and encouraging teamwork.
 
The workshop is designed for those who have been promoted recently into a supervisory management role or for those who have been there for some time but need to improve their leadership and management skills. To book: email - info@biztrainers.co.nz or call 04 974 8790

venue: Jo Frances Photography Studio, 13 Jessie Street, Lower Hutt
description:
Join us for an exciting and practical evening, where we’ll dive deep into the art of posing people—specifically family, groups and business headshot. This workshop is designed to strengthen your ability to confidently direct and arrange your subjects, whether you're working in a fast-paced session or a more posed setting.

You’ll also learn how to troubleshoot common posing challenges on the fly—awkward body angles, distracted children, or uneven groupings—while maintaining control and keeping your clients at ease.

Whether you're just starting out or looking to refine your posing skills, this workshop will equip you with practical tools and renewed confidence for your next session.

id: Rogue Sunday Jazz - Emma Hattaway-The Rogue and Vagabond, 18 Garrett St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Rogue Sunday Jazz - Emma Hattaway
venue: The Rogue and Vagabond, 18 Garrett St, Wellington
description:
The Rogue's regular Sunday afternoon jazz. Funky, jazzy, soulful jazz. Beer, hangs, and jazz, on a Sunday, perfect!

This week featuring local bassist Emma Hattaway and her band.

Join Emma and friends for an evening celebrating two of jazz’s most original voices. One set explores the sharp, playful language of Thelonious Monk; the other dives into the bold, emotional world of Charles Mingus.

As if their voices weren’t daring enough, the band will explore new takes and outlandish arrangements of Monk and Mingus tunes—adding to the ongoing conversation these legends continue to inspire.

Music from 5pm, FREE ENTRY - koha for the band encouraged

id: Pottery - Throwing - Next Step-Wellington Potters Association, 130 Grant Rd, Thorndon, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Pottery - Throwing - Next Step
venue: Wellington Potters Association, 130 Grant Rd, Thorndon, Wellington
description:
Extend your skills in this Next Step pottery course, aimed at those who already have the basics. (Held at Wellington Potters' Association, 130 Grant Road, Thorndon).

A follow-on course for those who have some experience of throwing on the wheel and would like some guidance to take their skills to the next stage.

You’ll learn how to “turn” your pots with more confidence and be able to make a variety of small to medium-sized projects. Basic glazing of your pots will also be covered.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
- Turn a pot
- Make a lidded container
- Make a rounded vase
- Form a reasonable sized bowl
- Do basic glazing

All materials included in course fee. Wear old clothes and footwear suitable for a workshop environment and bring an old towel.

id: Natural Textured Rings-Workspace Ōtaki, 6 Hewson Crescent, Ōtaki-Event Finder
name: Natural Textured Rings
venue: Workspace Ōtaki, 6 Hewson Crescent, Ōtaki
description:
Make your own personalised ring - a gift for yourself or someone special! :-)

Learn the basic technique first in copper or brass, and then craft your final piece in silver!

Over this taster class, you’ll be guided through the process of heating and texturing metal, cutting and shaping with traditional jewellery tools. Use feathers, leaves, or fabrics to create a unique texture for a beautiful ring!

Learn to measure your finger, cut metal to length and texture it without rolling mill, hammers and punches. Then use a jewellers torch, sandpaper and polishing, and your beautiful new ring will be ready to wear.

This 3-hour class is ideal for beginners, groups of friends and visitors to the city.

Included in the class fee are copper and brass for practising on, a sterling silver ring strip and all consumables such as sandpaper, solder and chemicals. Extra metals are available for purchase in the studio.

Kids aged 12 (or so) are welcome to attend the class, but any person under the age of 16 must be accompanied by adults.

id: Drawing And Painting For Beginners-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Drawing And Painting For Beginners
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Explore a range of painting and drawing techniques from ink and watercolor to impasto and realism using acrylic paint. Each week we will explore a different medium and subject to expand your knowledge, and confidence in your own artistic ability.

Bring along your own sketchbook (A4 or larger) All other course materials will be provided.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:

Use a variety of painting and brush techniques in your own work
Understand how light moves around an object
Blend and shade using wet and dry media
Mix and apply colour to your painting and drawings
Further develop your own painting and drawing style

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. id: Intro to Acrylic Painting - 8 week course-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Intro to Acrylic Painting - 8 week course
venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
description:
This is a foundational class that will enable you to make a painting of your choice! The course is open to people of any level of experience.

Bring in a reference or set up a still life and we will deconstruct how to paint it. You will leave with paintings as well as a toolbox for breaking any subject matter down into simple steps. Personalised tutor feedback will help you refine your skills and develop a unique style. At the beginning of each class there will be a practical demonstration.

Throughout the term we will cover the following:

- Materials and equipment
- Preparing the ground
- Designing the composition
- Colour relationships, warm and cool, colour mixing
- How to simplify the major shadows
- Subtleties of the mid tones
- Highlights, and other finishing touches
- When to stop painting (important!)
- Realism and style

Basic materials included. Students must be at least 18 years of age to attend this course.

Thursday evenings, 6 - 8 pm.
24 July - 11 September.

Welcome to "Rising Star," the hottest drag competition in Wellington - where the spotlight is on, the outfits are sparkling and the competition is FIERCE!

id: Entrepreneurial Skills for Artists Workshop-Adam Concert Room, NZSM Kelburn Campus, Victoria University, Gate 7, Kelburn Parade, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Entrepreneurial Skills for Artists Workshop
venue: Adam Concert Room, NZSM Kelburn Campus, Victoria University, Gate 7, Kelburn Parade, Wellington
description:
Spend your Saturday with fellow creatives at Leah Jane's "Entrepreneurial Skills for Artists" workshop! Let's chat about the skills and experience you need in your self-producing toolkit to bring sustainability, intention and agency to your creative practice.

In this workshop we will be discussing:


Fundraising and financing

Project planning and scheduling

Marketing and brand-building

Value mapping and community building

Pitching yourself and your work

And more!


Leah Jane will be bringing her experience as an independent artist, arts administrator and producer, as well as the knowledge she gained in her two-year Masters of Arts Management and Entrepreneurship (from the New School, New York City). Leah will be joined by special guests and a panel of industry leaders to discuss "pitching yourself and your work".

This workshop will be interactive and relaxed so bring yourself, your creative collaborators, and materials to write with. There will be opportunities to network and chat with other creatives, snacks and coffee, and a chance to ask all your burning questions.

Tickets are priced at:
$35 full price
$25 concession
$10 current students

All ticket proceeds will be going towards the costs of the event, koha for guests and Leah's fundraising efforts for her next New York adventure.

id: InDuna - Go High - EP Release-Moon, 167 Riddiford Street, Wellington-Event Finder
name: InDuna - Go High - EP Release
venue: Moon, 167 Riddiford Street, Wellington
description:
Join Afro-Kiwi artist InDuna to celebrate the release of his brand new EP, ‘Go High’, live at Moon, Wellington on Saturday 2nd August.

‘Go High’ is a gift from InDuna’s younger self to the artist he is today. It's an uplifting and reflective Afro-pop project inspired by his South African roots and journey of resilience. The EP is a reminder to keep dreaming boldly, no matter the obstacles.

Doors open: 9:00 PM
Show starts: 9:30 PM

Venue: Moon, 167 Riddiford Street, Newtown, Wellington
Moon is a wheelchair-accessible venue with both seated and standing options available.

When the NFC ticket bundle is purchased, fans will get exclusive access to a limited edition NFC-enabled EP, featuring the full EP plus unreleased demos and future tracks, delivered directly to your device before they’re available anywhere else. InDuna merchandise will also be available on the night — don’t miss it.

About InDuna:
Self-taught artist and producer InDuna blends Afro-pop with the vibrant spirit of his South African heritage. He was recently honoured with the Young Global Achiever Award at the 2024 Prince’s Trust Awards in London and recognised at Buckingham Palace by King Charles III.

His music has reached global ears, with his track ‘Dreams’, written for the documentary Ink and Gold: An Artist’s Journey to Olympic Glory, winning Best Original Song at the International Online Web Fest and climbing to #6 on the NZ Hot Singles Chart.

id: Wāhine Wānanga: Copyright and Intellectual Property in Te Āo Toi Māori-Toi Pōneke Arts Centre, 61-69 Abel Smith St, Te Aro, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Wāhine Wānanga: Copyright and Intellectual Property in Te Āo Toi Māori
venue: Toi Pōneke Arts Centre, 61-69 Abel Smith St, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Kia hiwa ra! Kia hiwa ra!

Nau mai, haere mai, whakatau mai ra!

Join us at Toi Pōneke for our second Wāhine Wānanga for artists.  A presentation from wāhine toa Lynell Tuffery Huria about copyright and intellectual property in Te Āo Toi Māori (The World of Māori Arts).

Lynell Tuffery Huria (Ngāti Ruanui, Ngāruahinerangi, Ngaa Rauru Kiitahi)
Lynell is recognised as the first Māori Patent Attorney and is acknowledged as a leading expert on indigenous intellectual property rights, Māori intellectual property and trade mark protection.

Over the last 30 years, Lynell has worked for a large intellectual property specialist firm, advising a wide variety of clients including whanau, hapū, and iwi, sole traders, companies, and multi-national corporations.

Lynell is keen to continue to assist Māori to navigate the intellectual property system and develop new and innovative ways to protect our cultural heritage.

Wed 16 July, 5:30pm - 7:30pm
Toi Pōneke, 61 Abel Smith Street, Te Aro

Free entry - Limited spaces so booking is essential.

id: Do It Yourself Framing-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Do It Yourself Framing
venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
description:
Bring along a painting and a suitable frame, either a cheapo from Briscoes or a good second hand frame. We will provide the tools and matt board.
It’s a practical course where you will learn to prepare the frame, cut with a knife, measure and cut a matt with the matt cutter.
You will walk away with your painting framed, ready to hang and some useful knowledge about framing ready for sale, exhibition standards, D rings, swing tags, acid free archival materials, tape, and how to hang a painting on the wall.

What’s included in this workshop:
- Demonstration of the steps to framing your work
- assembling the tools you need
- choosing and cleaning frames
- how to size and cut an acid free mat
- what sort of tapes to use for each task
- various fixings for hanging and D-rings
- replacing acid leaching materials with foam board
- cutting techniques
- making and attaching labels and swing tags
- how to photograph your art

Hands-on session where you will learn to cut card, cut a window in the matt board, present, secure, tape, screw in D-ring, tie knots etc

All materials will be provided including knives, metal ruler, cutting board, crescent board for the mat, mat cutter, tape, d-ring, string.

What to bring along:
- your artwork to frame
- a suitable frame for the artwork A4 or smaller
- enthusiasm!

Thirty-minute lunch - bring a packed lunch to have in our historic home or explore the local cafes in Te Aro.

id: Silk Aquatint Printmaking-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Silk Aquatint Printmaking
venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
description:
Discover the silk aquatint, an accessible, non-toxic alternative print technique similar to collagraph printing whereby the texture of woven silk on the plate provides a ground to start building a design with varying tonal qualities. The outcome can be wonderfully detailed and painterly.

In this workshop you will learn -

- To identify appropriate silk to create an aquatint plate
- The importance of preparing an appropriate matrix for the silk
- About the different effects created by different types of media applied to the print matrix
- To make an aquatint plate
- To print an aquatint plate

This workshop is open to beginners as well as seasoned printers.

Basic materials included. Bring drawings or designs to help you get started and wear clothes you are not precious about.

Half hour break for lunch. Bring your own packed lunch to have in the historic Inverlochy house or explore the local Te Aro cafes.

You must be at least 16 years of age to attend this course.

Saturday & Sunday, 2-3 August, 10 am - 3 pm daily.
