id: Cocktails and Constellations-The White Swan, 109 Main Street, Greytown-Event Finder
name: Cocktails and Constellations
venue: The White Swan, 109 Main Street, Greytown
description:
Hillview Property Investments bring you a very special evening of stars, stories and superb cocktails.

Join us at 5:30pm for a welcome cocktail and canapés. Then, armed with the most excellent time machines, Hari and Sam from Star Safari — an astrobiologist and an astrophysicist — take alien spotting to a whole new level. Using their extra-large telescopes, they’ll take you back in time. You’ll see double when looking at Alpha Centauri, star clusters that make diamonds jealous, and galaxies so far away their light set out before Greytown even existed.

As a bonus — and for your eyes only — you’ll get exclusive access to the Wishing Well Cluster to make a wish (or several).

All this whilst imbibing on delightful Greytown Distilling Company gin cocktails from a private suite at The White Swan. This will be a memorable night indeed.

This is a partially outdoor event so rug up. Restricted, ages 18+. Ticket includes two gin cocktails.
Plus you can get 30% off accommodation at The White Swan - a promotion code will be sent to you after your ticket purchase.

Tickets limited to 15 people per event, to ensure an intimate and engaging experience. If this event is postponed by the organisers, due to unsuitable weather other dates will be offered.

Proudly sponsored by Hillview Property Investments.

id: Expressive Watercolour - 8 Week Course-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Expressive Watercolour - 8 Week Course
venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
description:
Watercolour is special because of the fluid properties that produce spontaneous and unique results. The inability to anticipate exactly what the paint will do makes watercolour an exciting medium to work with.

In this course we will learn to set the conditions for surprising and beautiful accidents to occur on the page. By incorporating these looser abstract elements into representational paintings we can convey heightened emotions in our work.

Throughout the term we will cover the following:

- The wet into wet technique to achieve one of a kind paint interactions.
- Learn about transparent colour mixing to create luminosity in your paintings.
- Use marbling to find organic shapes and patterns.
- Study the relationship between line and colour and the different ways they can be combined to find a personal style.
- Experiment with composition through collage.

Each class we will look at examples of historic and contemporary painting, and discuss how to selectively incorporate references into your work. Over the term you will build up a visual style and body of work.

Whether you’re new to watercolour or looking to expand your range, this course offers an opportunity to explore the expressive potential of watercolour.

Basic materials included.

Mornings:
Wednesdays, 10 am - 1 pm.
23 July - 10 September.

Evenings:
Mondays, 6-8 m
21 July - 8 September.

id: Photography - Unlocking the Secrets to Captivating Images-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Photography - Unlocking the Secrets to Captivating Images
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Why do some photographs linger in our memories while others seem forgettable and repetitive? Why do we scroll through Instagram and barely recall what we saw five minutes later?

This course will help you find the answers to these questions and show you how to transform your photographs into extraordinary, captivating, and memorable images

Elevate your photography from ordinary to extraordinary and ensure your work stands out in the digital age. Creating captivating photographs and understanding what makes a photograph engaging is something every photographer should master.

Camera settings are essential, but once you know them, you need to learn how to take photographs that stir emotions, impact your audience, and leave a lasting impression.
After all, isn’t that the true purpose of photography? People don’t want to see the same landscapes or flowers they’ve seen thousands of times. But how do you turn what you love into something that makes people go, "Wow"?

Captivation in photography means stopping a viewer in their tracks, making them look, feel, and connect. It’s about delivering a photograph that enthrals, evokes profound emotions, and shifts perspectives.

In a world brimming with images, only a few have the power to truly captivate and linger in our memories.

This pioneering course is your gateway to mastering the art of creating captivating photographs at a time when AI-generated images are saturating our visual landscape. Create something genuine and memorable—images that spark curiosity, evoke emotions, and inspire changes in perception. It's time to define your unique style, refine your vision, and make your mark.

Course Outcomes

By the end of the five-week course, you’ll be able to:

-Identify the foundational elements that transform an ordinary image into a captivating one.
-Create photographs that make people say "Wow" by applying techniques that add a spark of wonder to your shots.
-Infuse your photographs with curiosity, making each frame a source of intrigue and interest.
-Understand why some images linger in memory and how to make your photographs unforgettable.
-Develop a unique style and vision that sets your work apart in the crowded digital landscape.

Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

Prerequisites
This course is perfect for you if you:

Aim to elevate your photography from good to mind-blowing.
Are eager to discover the secret ingredients that make photographs unforgettable (all backed by research and science).
Feel passionate about photography but need fresh ideas on what to photograph and how to truly stand out.
Wish to explore and evolve your genre and style.

5 sessions, 4 x Thu 5:30 PM – 7:30 PM plus a Saturday field trip
Wellington High School
Presented by Ana Lyubich
$159 incl. GST

id: Raising Great Kids In An Overindulgent World-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Raising Great Kids In An Overindulgent World
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Parenting today delivers unprecedented challenges – are you wondering what went wrong and somehow ended up living with a child you don’t recognise as should be belonging to you? Get a new perspective, an easy-to-understand model to follow and tools to help you to raise likeable and respectful children in an age of over-indulgence.

This workshop will be a confronting one that will expose you to the risks that children face in this modern overindulgent world. Many have become used to being the constant centre of attention and are unable to delay gratification and aren’t competent in everyday skills.

They have few self-care skills and skills relating to others, can’t take personal responsibility and don’t know what is enough or what is “normal” for others – these children end up having a difficult time of it in life and you will too.

You’ll take away new insight and knowledge plus strategies that you can apply that very night to help your child to be a responsible, likeable and respectful person.

By the end of the session, you’ll be able to:
- Reflect on the current context parents are faced with today
- Find the relevant research
- Practise the parenting tools and discuss the model
- Know where to go to get support

Aimed at parents, grandparents and caregivers of children of all ages.

Presented by Madeleine Taylor.

id: Writers on Mondays: Making and Mending-Te Marae, Te Papa Tongarewa, 55 Cable Street, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Writers on Mondays: Making and Mending
venue: Te Marae, Te Papa Tongarewa, 55 Cable Street, Wellington
description:
MAKING AND MENDING: CADENCE CHUNG, GREGORY KAN, JIAQIAO LIU, AND NINA MINGYA POWLES
A poet’s toolbox is filled with techniques to help them kick-start or rebuild a poem, but sometimes the tried and true tricks aren’t enough. How can poets engage with other forms of art and artmaking to challenge and reinvent how poetry is written? New Zealand Poet Laureate Chris Tse talks with Cadence Chung (Mad Diva), Gregory Kan (Clay Eaters), Jiaqiao Liu (Dear Alter), and Nina Mingya Powles (In the Hollow of the Wave) about how their creative pursuits and interests outside poetry shape and inform their latest collections.

Writers on Mondays is presented with the Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa, Circa Theatre and Phantom Billstickers National Poetry Day, and is supported by the Letteri Family.

id: The Carol Bean Band-Hilltop, 17 Upland Road, Kelburn, Wellington-Event Finder
name: The Carol Bean Band
venue: Hilltop, 17 Upland Road, Kelburn, Wellington
description:
Gate opens 6.30pm Music Starts 7pm Saturday 9 August 2025
The Carol Bean Band play a mix of jazzy blues with a heavy helping of original songs and stylish instrumentation.  Carol Bean – vocals and guitar, Costa Botes – guitar(s), George Packard – upright bass, and Andrew Grayson – drums. 
English-born, California-raised, Carol was influenced by the West Coast music of the 60s and the blues of Mississippi John Hurt, Mance Lipscomb, Lightnin’ Hopkins, and Doc Watson. At LA’s Ash Grove and McCabe’s Music Store she was taught her picking style from a young Ry Cooder who encouraged her to buy the Martin guitar she still plays today. Carol has fronted several bands in New Zealand and recorded 3 studio albums, all on Spotify. She continues to perform at the Wellington Roomfulla Blues Club and with the Kelburn Viaduct Municipal Ensemble Jug Band.
"Carol’s singing is versatile, vibrant, and delivers an earthy quality to her songs." Tom Villano, LA
"… when the mood drops she reveals a more intimate, reflective side…." Graham Reid
"The first three songs of Next Bus Out perfectly set the album up for the interesting  journey that is to come." Nick Bollinger.
Costa is a veteran independent filmmaker with several award winning short films and feature length documentaries to his credit, including the notorious ‘mock doc’ Forgotten Silver, which he made with Peter Jackson. For the last two decades he has created a run of films celebrating individuals who are quirky, creative, passionate, and above all, persistent (Struggle No More, The Last Dogs of Winter, Act of Kindness, Angie, When The Cows Come Home).  These films have included studies of musicians (Paddy Burgin's Wooden Box Band, Nigel Gavin’s Circus, and The Shot Band/ Hobnails @ The Paramount Theatre) because Costa has been a persistent closet musician himself. He has had stints with Chris and Eva Prowse, and Carol Bean's Mount Misery String Band. When he was younger, Costa wanted to move his fingers really fast. Now he just tries to put them in the right place, song by song, and man - does he ever. “Tasty”, “Amazing”, “Great playing”.
See Costa Botes | NZ On Screen & Costa Botes Lone Pine Films (vimeo.com)
George is a professional musician and tutor on Whitireia Polytechnic’s Music Programme, trained classically on the cello. George’s first improvisational experiences were playing ukulele along with the Rolling Stones, John Mayall and The Band (in his bedroom).  With little market for improvisational ukulele he took up the double bass.
George enjoys playing in bands that push the envelope and give expression to the human soul. He has played extensively in many Wellington groups (including currently with the Rag Poets band), appearing a number of times for the Wellington International Festival of the Arts, undertaking national tours for Chamber Music New Zealand, and backing overseas artists in New Zealand. His playing ranges from classical to jazz, to Latin, to ethnic fusion to Americana and country. He believes - at a fundamental level - that music is about human beings making sense of the world and themselves, and about helping heal the world.
Andrew is also the drummer for the band Ghostplane (Beneath the Sleepy Lagoon; Panther Valley Country Club (Arch Hill Records), which includes Phoenix Foundation members). Not only has he joined our team, but his passion is surfing - so let's say he's the youngest and the fittest.
Not for profit, supporting our dedicated musicians. Suggested donation $30
Come along and enjoy this gig in our special space, up close and personal.

id: Natural Texture Earrings and Pendants-Workspace Studios Ltd, 65 Abel Smith St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Natural Texture Earrings and Pendants
venue: Workspace Studios Ltd, 65 Abel Smith St, Wellington
description:
A quick taster class that’s ideal as a weekend outing for friends, or as a treat for you! In three short hours, learn to craft an amazing pair of textured metal earrings - from scratch!

Over this taster class, you’ll be guided through the process of heating and texturing metal, cutting and shaping with traditional jewellery tools. After completing this class, you will have one pair of beautiful earrings to wear away or gift to someone special!

You will practice on smaller texture samples to work out what texture and what metal you want to go with, and then move on to creating your earrings in warm copper, yellow brass and sterling silver - with solid sterling silver earring hooks or posts.

Your class materials pack includes everything you need for the class to make a super cool pair of beautiful earrings. You are welcome to purchase extra materials for larger pieces at the studio.

We use quality pre-made sterling silver earring wires, or earring posts with silicone stud backs for these taster classes so that you can focus on making the main part of the earrings and know that your findings will be just perfect.

Kids aged 12 (or so) are welcome to attend the class, but an enrolled parent or caregiver must accompany anyone under the age of 16.

id: Kiki's Delivery Service (魔女の宅急便)-Embassy of Japan, Level 18, 100 Willis Street, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Kiki's Delivery Service (魔女の宅急便)
venue: Embassy of Japan, Level 18, 100 Willis Street, Wellington
description:
Come along to our free Japanese Film night, co-organised with the Japan Foundation, Sydney!

Synopsis
Discover Kiki’s Delivery Service, a fantastic coming-of-age tale full of magic, adventure, and self-discovery from the sensational imagination of Academy Award–winning director Hayao Miyazaki (2002, Best Animated Feature, Spirited Away). Kiki is an enterprising young girl who must follow tradition to become a full-fledged witch. Venturing out with only her chatty black cat, Jiji, Kiki flies off for the adventure of a lifetime. Landing in a far-off city, she sets up a high-flying delivery service and begins a wonderful experience of independence and responsibility as she finds her place in the world. Rarely has the animator's art been so brilliantly rendered as in this delightfully imaginative film that will entertain boys and girls everywhere.

Director: MIYAZAKI Hayao / Classification: PG / Year: 1989 Genre: Anime, Children/Family
Language: Japanese with English subtitles

Copyright:© 1989 Eiko Kadono - Studio Ghibli - N

A short Japan Video Topics DVD will be shown from 5:15pm before the start of the film at 5:30pm. Free admission is based on a first-come, first-served basis, with a full theatre capacity of 40 people. No food is permitted in the theatre

description:

Description
Live storytelling is an artform unto itself, requiring different skills and techniques from standup comedy or prose writing. In this four-part workshop, you’ll learn:

- Creative writing exercises and daily practices to to find meaningful stories from your life
- Tools for crafting a compelling personal narrative
- Techniques to build suspense, drama, and humour into your stories

description:

Mikaela Nyman is from the autonomous, demilitarised Åland Islands in Finland. Her first poetry collection in English, Anatomy of Sand, follows on from her climate fiction novel Sado. These two urgent contemporary voices join Tamara Tulitua in a conversation about rising seas, political and personal poetry, the local and global.

Writers on Mondays is presented with the Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa, Circa Theatre and Phantom Billstickers National Poetry Day, and is supported by the Letteri Family.

id: Forest & Bird Wellington Cryptics & Crosswords-listening to Birds-The Garden Room at St Peter's on Willis, 170 Victoria St, Te Aro, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Forest & Bird Wellington Cryptics & Crosswords-listening to Birds
venue: The Garden Room at St Peter's on Willis, 170 Victoria St, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Register now for “Cryptics and cross words: listening to our native birds”

[NB: This event was postponed from 1 May due to very bad weather and high winds].

When: Thursday, 24 July 2025. 7:00 p.m St Peter’s Church Ground Floor Garden Room accessed via a gate on Ghuznee Street behind the Church, or via 170 Victoria Street, Wellington. [Wheelchair accessible].

Ever wonder – Which bird is that calling? How many of them are there?

Hear from Professor Stephen Marsland about a fascinating application of mathematics to understand bird song and his software designed to answer those questions. Twelve or so years ago Stephen decided that sounds -- specifically bird sounds -- could be described as mathematical objects, and therefore could be used for conservation.

Stephen Marsland is a Professor of Mathematics and Data Science at Victoria University of Wellington. This has given him more opportunities than are reasonable, for a mathematician to work with taonga species of Aotearoa New Zealand. It has also led to the AviaNZ software and research programme, which tries to recognise the calls of New Zealand birds, and turn them into estimates of their abundance in an area. The software is freely available for anybody to use.
When not wrangling kiwi and other birds he works on mathematical questions in evolutionary game theory (including why humans cooperate, and why sexual reproduction arose) and infinite dimensional geometry).
Register for catering purposes here at EventFinda.
Agenda
6:30 p.m. Doors Open and Light refreshments served
7:00 p.m. Talk start
8:30 p.m. Wrap-up.

- Formulate greetings, introductions and other expressions for basic everyday communication
- Use the rules of pronunciation
- Enquire and reply (formally and informally) about people's names, work situation, origin and family
- Recognise the verbs essere (to be) and avere (to have) and use the present tense in basic phrases
- Order, offer, accept and refuse food and drink in a cafe at a basic level

Presented by Juliana Stroghiu.

id: Crime Writing - An Introduction-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Crime Writing - An Introduction
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Have you always dreamed of writing compelling fiction about murder, mayhem and where to put the body? Join successful crime author Cat Connor as she shows you where and how!

This course is designed to introduce new writers (and more experienced writers) to the world of crime writing. You will be looking at writing basics, crime genres, characters, story construction, research, plotting and story arcs, outlining (yay or nay), heroes and villains and finish with log lines and synopsis writing, among other things.

This is an intense but fun course designed and taught by Cat Connor who teaches writing via Writers Plot Bookshop and is also an internationally published crime writer of multiple books.

The objective is to encourage and support you by imparting knowledge that you can apply going forward and find real enjoyment in writing crime (or whatever you go on to write).

Bring notebook and pens.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:

Create an outline for a crime novel or short story.
Construct characters’ maps and believable characters.
Demonstrate and recognize active and passive writing.
Develop sound and robust research techniques.
Use plot diagrams to enhance an outline.
Construct loglines, taglines, and blurbs.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

6 weeks, Sat 9:30 AM – 11:30 AM
Wellington High School
Presented by Cat Connor
$159 incl. GST

id: The Eastern-Abandoned Taproom Petone, 38 Fitzherbert St, Petone, Lower Hutt-Event Finder
name: The Eastern
venue: Abandoned Taproom Petone, 38 Fitzherbert St, Petone, Lower Hutt
description:
The Eastern are a string band that roars like a punk band, that swings like a gospel band, that drinks like a country band, that works like a bar band, that hopes like folk singers, and sings love songs like union songs, and writes union songs like love songs, and wants to slow dance and stand on tables, all at the same time. Four albums and well over 1000 shows deep The Eastern have played and toured with Fleetwood Mac, Steve Earle
and Old Crow Medicine Show amongst others, ticking off miles, countries and new friends and fans wherever they get to roaming.

‘No Depression’ magazine noted they were “One of the best modern roots acts, from any country”. Both Radio NZ and the NZ Herald described them as “National Treasures” and The Heralds Graham Reid called singer Adam McGrath “NZ’s toughest minded songwriter”. NZ country legend Barry Saunders simply called
them “The Truth.”

Built around the songs of 2024 New Zealand Music Award’s folk artist of the year Adam McGrath and Banjo
legend Jess Shanks, The Eastern continue to prove they are a band of brothers and sisters you can’t help but
believe in.

THE FIRST TIME IN A LONG DAMN TIME, HERE WE GO WITH OUR OL PAL ROB JOASS SINGING THE TRUE GOOD SONGS!
In association with the wellington bluegrass society with a special price for WBS members, for members head here for booking bluegrass@xtra.co.nz or phone (04)477 006
Doors 7pm

id: Cringeworthy: The 90's-Circa Theatre, 1 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Cringeworthy: The 90's
venue: Circa Theatre, 1 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Cringeworthy – 90s!
A high-octane explosion of ‘90s nostalgia!

Written and devised by Andrea Sanders
Produced by Beatgirl Productions
Starring Andrea Sanders, Devon Neiman, Jared Pallesen and Emma Katene

Following the success of Cringeworthy ’60s, ’70s and ’80s, this show pays homage to NZ music and culture in the last decade of the 20th century. Expect a ‘rad’ mix of local and international hits delivered with snappy dance moves, scintillating vocals and a generous dollop of cheesy comedy.

The 90s was a decade bursting with diverse musical genres, from boy bands and girl groups to MMMBop and hip hop, the swing revival (Mambo No. 5), country (Achy Breaky Heart), The Macarena and re-releases of iconic hits such as To Sir With Love, Silly Love Songs, Unchained Melody and Get Down on It (can you dig it??).

On the local scene, legends such as Crowded House, Dave Dobbyn, The Exponents, Margaret Urlich, Supergroove, True Bliss, Ardijah, South Side of Bombay and The Chills gave us heavenly pop hits that have become Kiwi classics.

In some ‘fly’ outfits, Cringeworthy – the ’90s packages the hits of the decade (including Can’t Touch This, Weather With You, Love Shack and How Bizarre) with some unforgettable fashion trends including flannel shirts, baggy jeans, tracksuits and chokers. These energetic styles are woven together with a witty narrative reflecting the lifestyle, news events and culture of the time – smelling like Teen Spirit!

What’s the time Mr Wolf? Time to grab your ticket to ride this retro rollercoaster! Nostalgia invites you to relive a decade that still resonates today. Get ready to party like its 1999!

Reviews:
“A fantabulous blast from the past, high energy, fun and a belly full of laughs”
“A unique blend of uplifting vocals, brilliant choreography and personality personified!”

id: Harvest Moon-Hilltop, 17 Upland Road, Kelburn, Wellington-Event Finder

Americana and Country music band Harvest Moon feature a dazzling array of instruments including pedal steel, mandolin, guitars, banjo, accordion, and dobro, playing a diverse collection of classics from legends like Johnny Cash, John Prine, Dwight Yoakam, and Neil Young. The Wellington-based band’s front-man, lead vocalist Rob Reid provides a powerful and smooth singing style. Founding member & multi instrumentalist Garrett Evans plays pedal steel, dobro, guitars and sings vocals too. Dave Allen is Harvest Moon’s lead guitarist and banjo player - he also plays in Salty Hearts, and Hogsnort Bulldogs Goodtime Show. Another original member, Wayne Mills plays keys, accordion, bass and sings. A veteran of NZ’s vibrant 60s and 70s music scene, bassist Frits Stigter brings a wealth of experience and groove. On percussion - Robert Antonio is another well-known personality in the close-knit Wellington musical scene.
Come along to this special space and enjoy these guys playing up close and personal.

id: Retirement Reinvented-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Retirement Reinvented
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Whether you’re already retired, or planning ahead, this practical workshop will help you to reflect, re-envision and re-vitalise your life and develop a plan for your future, on your own terms. (NZ citizen and residents free with ID, all others pay $109).

In your middle years, working, retired or somewhere in between? What’s next? Life is about much more than work or leisure, but most of us have given little thought to what “retirement” might mean.

It’s difficult to speculate what may happen in the future – but we can be proactive and take control.
This course offers insights into how to make the most of our time once we’re less focused on career and/or childrearing. It covers many of the issues people face when considering a move from current employment to a different lifestyle that includes more time to do the things we’ve always promised ourselves we’d do – “when we retire”.

After the workshop, you’ll be able to identify a number of common issues and potential ways to manage them when considering and planning your “rejuvenation”, rather than a retirement. We won’t cover financial planning, but will focus on some of the personal growth opportunities for living and making a conscious contribution to your community.

By the end of the day, you’ll have:
- Developed your own perspective on ageing and retirement in the 21st Century and identified what’s important to you
- Completed a personal life audit exercise and considered your strengths
- Explored possibilities in the major aspects of your life and identified potential challenges and strategies for overcoming them
- Developed a blueprint to maximise the best years of your life and developed a “future proofing” downsizing plan
- Considered options to include a sense of purpose and explored and implemented choices that provide you with that sense of purpose
Bring a pen and paper.

1 day, Sat 9:30 AM – 4:00 PM
Wellington High School
Presented by Angela Robertson

id: Cooking Classes-Sheila's Indian Kitchen, Ashton Fitchett Dr, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Cooking Classes
venue: Sheila's Indian Kitchen, Ashton Fitchett Dr, Wellington
description:
Authentic Indian cooking classes in Wellington with panaromic views over Wellington Harbour.

In each class, you will learn 4-5 recipes like: potato stuff roti, roasted eggplant curry, wholemeal, roti, naan; shahi paneer; dhal, samosa; palak paneer; gourmet chickpeas; vegetable korma; gulab jamun; kheer; mango lassi; masala chai, and many more...

The classes start at 6 pm or 10:30 am on weekends and weekdays with a 2-hour session followed by a dinner or lunch afterwards. The ingredients, copies of recipes, organic karma drink will be provided with a full course meal in a banquet setting. Custom made classes available for gluten free, dairy free and any other food intolerance and dietary requirements.The ingredients, recipes, complimentary organic karma drinks will be provided with a full course meal.

There are 2 to 8 people in each class in purpose built cooking studio. Also a private cooking classes available.

The menu for the class can be:

1) Spicy potato stuffed paratha and roti, rajasthani tomato relish, aalu matter or spicy peas- potato curry, roasted cumin yogurt raita and fresh mint- coriander chutney.

2) Shahi Paneer (cottage cheese cubes with spices and rich tomato-cashew gravy), garlic coriander naan, cumin jeera basmati rice and sweet fragrant rice pudding with cardamom. Also I will teach how to make fresh paneer.

3) Roasted eggplant curry, plain whole wheat chapatti or roti, jeera aaloo or potato curry, Tuar dahl (split yellow lentil) and Basmati rice with homemade pickle.

4) Palak paneer (creamy spinach curry with cubes of paneer), jeera rice (basmati rice with fragrant spices, panjabi chhole or spicy chickpeas curry and mango lassi. Also fresh paneer making.

5) Khadi (chickpeas fritters in yogurt and chickpeas flour soupy gravy), Aloo-Gobhi (cauliflower and potato curry),  savoury wraps with herbs and spices, fresh pickle and basmati rice.

The total cost is $130 per person, this includes ingredient cost. (As an alternative we also sell cooking class gift vouchers.The food options are unlimited and the class provides fresh and best ingredients)
Please contact for booking: indiancooking@xtra.co.nz

So just bring your taste buds! and Enjoy!!

id: Delaney Davidson - Anniversary Tour-Meow, 9 Edward St, Te Aro, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Delaney Davidson - Anniversary Tour
venue: Meow, 9 Edward St, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
With multiple album Anniversaries this year, Delaney Davidson takes to the road in July to celebrate his extensive and star studded catalogue with special band The Anniversaries.

15 years ago, Delaney Davidson joined Reverend Beat Man - cult figure, gospel trash preacher, and founder of the hugely influential Swiss record label VOODOO RHYTHM RECORDS, to release “Self Decapitation” and a year later “Bad Luck Man”.

Watch the Video “I’m So Depressed” , from the album “Back Luck Man”

For Radio - Download “I’m So Depressed”

Self Decapitation had such hits as Little Heart (Silver Scroll Finalist 2011) and barnstormer Dirty Dozen while Bad Luck Man had You’re a Loser (country music song of the year 2012), aswell as I’m So Depressed, and evergreen Time Has Gone. These albums cemented him into the Voodoo Rhythm Family and saw him become a distinct cult figure of the European Touring circuit.


Generally dealing with the darker side of things, Delaney Davidson has been described as “being the reigning king of capturing the essence of “Noir” in Country and Folk Music, pushing at the framework and preconceptions of roots music with his brand of modern gothic Americana.” (Post to Wire).

Having spent the last 20 years as travelling “troubadour" around the globe, sometimes solo, sometimes with accomplices, but always with his Ghost Orchestra, Delaney Davidson has found new focus embracing a love of Aotearoa.

Through his collaborative work with Troy Kingi “ Black Sea, Golden Ladder”, his visual art work with Tame Iti, and his most current album “Out Of My Head” produced by Merk, he has featured such varied talents as Hayley Westenra and Reb Fountain and has toured with Chamber Music New Zealand - all the while continuing to reinvent concepts and challenge expectations, and gaining respect and admiration from audiences.


"Incontestably one of Aotearoa’s most influential and lauded contemporary songwriters” Under The Radar

Delaney Davidson now takes his band of Anniversaries on the local roads around Aotearoa, don’t miss a night of wry sense of humour, some theatre of unease, and a rocking collection of bangers from his extensive back catalogue as he celebrates the music that got him where he is today.

Delaney Davidson Anniversary Tour

Fri July 11 - Double Whammy, Auckland

Fri August 1 - Theatre Royal, Nelson
Sat 2 August - Loons, Lyttelton

General tickets – 9am, Monday 24 March

Tickets from Banished Music.

id: Princess Chelsea's Midwinter Ball-Meow Nui, 92 Vivian Street, Te Aro, Wellington, 6011, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Princess Chelsea's Midwinter Ball
venue: Meow Nui, 92 Vivian Street, Te Aro, Wellington, 6011, Wellington
description:
PRINCESS CHELSEA’S MIDWINTER BALL
SWORDS AND SORCERY - Fantasy on The Big Screen
with your host TOM SAINSBURY

SATURDAY 19 JULY - WINTERGARDEN, THE CIVIC, AUCKLAND (ALL AGES) *
SATURDAY 26 JULY - MEOW NUI, WELLINGTON **

With special guests THE CIRCLING SUN & GOLDEN AXE *
GRECCO ROMANK & LUKE BUDA **

‘The Wintergarden will host many, many more incredible events, but it will never host something like the mesmerising Princess Chelsea and Twin Peaks crossover again’ - Rolling Stone

This winter, the Civic Wintergarden (ALL AGES) and Meow Nui (18+) Wellington will be transformed into a world of fantasy! Princess Chelsea’s Midwinter Ball returns, this year with a new theme: SWORDS AND SORCERY - Fantasy on The Big Screen. With your esteemed host comedian Tom Sainsbury, and live performances from Princess Chelsea & The Dream Warriors in both centres, with Auckland guests The Circling Sun & Golden Axe, while Wellington will be treated to sets from Grecco Romank & Luke Buda.

In the shimmering and VHS-heavy age of the early 1980s, a treasure trove of cinematic fantasy was thrust upon us. Gleaming swords and potent spells in Excalibur, the ethereal beauty and terror of Legend, valiant quests of The Sword and The Sorcerer, Ladyhawke, The Beastmaster, Willow, Dragonslayer, and the mighty & muscular quests of Conan The Barbarian. And let us not forget the timeless enchantments of pure fantasy with The Neverending Story, the delightful Princess Bride, the poignant Last Unicorn, and the unforgettable shape of Labyrinth.

So, brave adventurers, will you join us to celebrate this golden age? How will you dress to impress as visions of enchanted lands and heroic feats conjure a costume fit for fantasy?

Called by many as ‘the show of 2024’, last year’s Twin Peaks themed Midwinter Ball was a revelation, and a dress up party for the ages. A sold out Wintergarden heaved with 650 guests dressed as Log Ladies, Agent Dale Coopers, and even a giant slice of cherry pie… and oh, so much more.

Princess Chelsea and her band The Dream Warriors delighted the audience with a blazing set of originals alongside covers of Julee Cruise, Angelo Badalamenti and In Heaven from Lynch’s Eraserhead. This wild and unforgettable night has been lovingly captured and presented as a four song tribute to David Lynch, due for imminent release.
For 2024’s Twin Peaks-themed ball, no expenses were spared on transforming the venue into the quaint town of Twin Peaks. Decoration which featured lasers, an indoor pine forest, a shrine to Laura Palmer and a replica of the infamous Red Room, we can only expect magic and mystery from 2025’s fantasy- themed ball.

“I’m not giving too much away but obviously we will need a medieval sword fight” - Princess Chelsea

If last year’s ball was anything to go by, I don't think she is joking - and further shenanigans will undoubtedly ensue. Expect the Civic and Meow Nui to be transformed into a world of fantasy.

Earlybird tickets are on sale Friday at 10am. Book your evening, and swan down the red carpet dressed in your favourite fantasy-inspired outfits. Portraits will be taken on the night, and prizes for best dressed.

id: Natural Textured Rings-Workspace Studios Ltd, 65 Abel Smith St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Natural Textured Rings
venue: Workspace Studios Ltd, 65 Abel Smith St, Wellington
description:
Make your own personalised ring - a gift for yourself or someone special! :-)

Learn the basic technique first in copper or brass, and then craft your final piece in silver!

Over this taster class, you’ll be guided through the process of heating and texturing metal, cutting and shaping with traditional jewellery tools. Use feathers, leaves, or fabrics to create a unique texture for a beautiful ring!

Learn to measure your finger, cut metal to length and texture it without rolling mill, hammers and punches. Then use a jewellers torch, sandpaper and polishing, and your beautiful new ring will be ready to wear.

This 3-hour class is ideal for beginners, groups of friends and visitors to the city.

Included in the class fee are copper and brass for practising on, a sterling silver ring strip and all consumables such as sandpaper, solder and chemicals. Extra metals are available for purchase in the studio.

Kids aged 12 (or so) are welcome to attend the class, but any person under the age of 16 must be accompanied by adults.

id: D. H. Lawrence's The Fox-Gryphon Theatre, 22 Ghuznee St, Te Aro, Wellington-Event Finder
name: D. H. Lawrence's The Fox
venue: Gryphon Theatre, 22 Ghuznee St, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Premiere production of D.H.Lawrence’s The Fox adapted for the stage by Keith Scott, Dunedin playwright. Directed by Annabel Hensley

It is 1918, immediately after the armistice which ended the Great War. Two women struggle to run a small farm in rural England and are moderately content. Their comfortable, albeit unfulfilling lives, are disrupted by two visitors. A fox has begun to take their hens and a young soldier arrives. These seemingly unrelated events combine and clash with unexpected consequences. The play explores the dynamics of power play when instincts are triggered that are as old as life itself.

The play explores gender roles, sexuality, femininity, and the pity of war, with Scott’s adaptation maintaining the authenticity of Lawrence’s original work.

Mindful Awareness – One-Day Workshop

Course is free for NZ citizens and residents (please bring photo ID when attending workshop). If you are not a NZ citizen or resident a fee of $149 will apply, please phone the office on 04 385 8919 to register.

“If we don’t know what we’re doing, how can we do what we want?”

A hands-on, one-day workshop blending mindfulness, neuroscience, and self-awareness to help you feel better, relate better, and live with more clarity and purpose.

Simple tools to soothe stress and calm your system

Escape the chill and ignite your creativity at our exclusive Winter Warmers candle making workshop, hosted in partnership with the beloved The Botanist in Lyall Bay!

Join Wellington Candle Co. for a truly unique and premium experience designed for friends, dates, or anyone looking to cozy up this winter with a touch of handcrafted luxury.

What to Expect at this Premium Experience:

Craft Your Signature Scent:
Dive into the meditative art of candle making! You'll learn the secrets behind selecting and blending premium fragrance oils to create a soothing aroma that's uniquely yours.

Your Handcrafted Masterpiece:
Guided by Wellington Candle Co., you'll pour your very own 250g wood-wick candle using high-quality soy wax, all housed in a beautiful, large white glass jar with an elegant wooden lid.

The Botanist's Delights:

Bubbles or Brews:
Your ticket includes one complimentary glass of bubbles or a refreshing non-alcoholic drink to enjoy as you create and mingle. Additional coffees or drinks can be purchased directly from The Botanist's cafe.

You hereby waive, release, and discharge any and all rights and claims against Wellington Candle Co. and its staff for any personal injury, property damage, or other claims arising from your participation in the workshop or incidents on the premises (including, but not limited to, slips and falls, or burns). id: The Voice That Mobilises Readers - Creative Writing Workshop-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
name: The Voice That Mobilises Readers - Creative Writing Workshop
venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
description:
A story runs through it -What is the voice that mobilises readers?

Research explains why certain forms of storytelling are especially effective at leaving readers with the desire to act on ideas. If you want readers to walk with you into issues that are important to you, this is your chance to find out how.

Marilyn will share some evidence regarding effective voice and content, along with suggestions to apply the research. You’ll read a few samples and have time to jot down and discuss your own starting points. Finally, there will be time to talk through some strategies to help you prepare for the facts of issue-based speech in this time.

This information applies to memoir, fictional stories, and many other forms of communication that aim to galvanise an audience. The principles are beneficial regardless of your experience, because all communication is based on finding a voice.

id: The Racket Lounge: Prelude-Bedlam and Squalor, Upstairs, 18 Garrett Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Event Finder
name: The Racket Lounge: Prelude
venue: Bedlam and Squalor, Upstairs, 18 Garrett Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Grab a spot on our couch and enjoy the noise at The Racket Lounge, a chill classical music series featuring up-and-coming Pōneke classical and jazz musicians.

Last year the NZSQ Trust launched the Racket Lounge, a concert series for classical and jazz musicians with experience ranging from students to pros to freely express their creativity in a non-traditional concert setting. It was a huge success, with over 250 audience members and 52 artists over our four sessions. Audiences were raving about the musical variety and great talent they found at the Racket Lounge, and as one audience member commented; “Well done…do it again!” So, we listened, and the Racket Lounge is back for round two! Once again hosted at Bedlam & Squalor (above the Rogue & Vagabond), we welcome audiences, composers and performers back for another four concerts full of innovative, fun, and chill music. From classical to pop covers, video game soundtracks to original compositions, there's something for everyone to sink their teeth into at The Racket Lounge!

Even if you've never been to a classical music concert before, this one is for you. With a 'Choose your price' model you can afford to give it a go - and you might even find something you like!

A Flexible Price, So You Can Take A Chance on Something New:
Our prices range from $5 to $100, just pick the ticket price you feel like paying. At The Racket Lounge, we believe everyone should have access to high-quality but affordable art. If you're a bit strapped for cash right now, but still want a good night out, no worries! Just book yourself a $5 ticket! If you can afford to pay a little more and want to do some good for your community, then pick one of our higher ticket prices and rest assured that your dollars are going towards funding great, accessible art in your city.

All proceeds from ticket sales will go directly into presenting the next Racket Lounge, including paying musicians and artists, hiring instruments and marketing costs. Plus, by choosing a higher price point, you're ensuring that we're able to continue to offer tickets at a lower price point for those who need it.

Please note: Bedlam & Squalor is a licenced venue, so under 18s must be accompanied by a parent or legal guardian. Everyone must bring ID.

id: Winter Natural Textured Rings - August-Workspace Studios Ltd, 65 Abel Smith St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Winter Natural Textured Rings - August
venue: Workspace Studios Ltd, 65 Abel Smith St, Wellington
description:
Make your own personalised ring - a gift for yourself or someone special! :-)

Learn the basic technique first in copper or brass, and then craft your final piece in silver!

Over this taster class, you’ll be guided through the process of heating and texturing metal, cutting and shaping with traditional jewellery tools. Use feathers, leaves, or fabrics to create a unique texture for a beautiful ring!

Learn to measure your finger, cut metal to length and texture it without rolling mill, hammers and punches. Then use a jewellers torch, sandpaper and polishing, and your beautiful new ring will be ready to wear.

This 3-hour class is ideal for beginners, groups of friends and visitors to the city.

Included in the class fee are copper and brass for practising on, a sterling silver ring strip and all consumables such as sandpaper, solder and chemicals. Extra metals are available for purchase in the studio.

Kids aged 12 (or so) are welcome to attend the class, but any person under the age of 16 must be accompanied by adults.

id: Life Drawing - 8 Week Tutored Art Lessons-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Life Drawing - 8 Week Tutored Art Lessons
venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
description:
The figure is an attractive and fascinating subject. In our tutored life drawing class we provide a supportive relaxed environment where you can learn figure drawing and practice from a variety of great models. Enjoy an evening of figure drawing with instruction and effective ideas to develop.

Each week we will examine tested drawing exercises that are great for practicing drawing the figure and valuable to help you problem solve. These exercises are effective and build your observational drawing. They build sensitivity to real shape, to gesture, form and the structure of figures. Our focus is to create figures that are convincing and have life.

Figure drawing is also valuable for extending an artist’s practice at any level. If you are beginning with figure work we will provide instruction, demonstrations and feed back to build your skill level.

All materials provided. Life model fees included in your tuition.

Thursday evenings, 6:30 - 8:30 pm.
24 July - 12 September.

id: Jewellery Making-Soldered Fidget Rings-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Jewellery Making-Soldered Fidget Rings
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Classic textured rings, with a unique and exciting twist! Learn to make your own fine jewellery fidget rings from copper, brass and silver - beginners welcome! All materials included in course fee.

Description
In this one-day workshop you are offered a hands-on opportunity to create custom rings with fun mobile components and unique textures. We'll also practice and build experience in the essential jeweller’s fabrication skills of sawing, filing, soldering, sanding and polishing.

What are fidget rings? Also known as spinner rings or stim rings, fidget rings have loose bands attached that can move and swivel around - it's interactive sculpture you can wear!

In this course you’ll be lead through the design and creation of custom copper and silver rings, with copper, brass and silver wire spinner bands adding novelty and movement to a classic ring design.

This course offers beginners a fun introduction to jewellery making, and for those with some jewellery experience, it offers a great way to advance and expand your making techniques to new levels.

All materials included in course fee.

Please wear closed-in footwear suitable for a workshop environment. bring a work apron if you have one or wear clothes you don’t mind getting a little grubby. Remember to bring your reading glasses if a have them.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

id: Mindfulness Meditation-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Mindfulness Meditation
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Being mindful can help make us more resilient to life’s challenges and give us more tools for dealing with strong emotions and stress or just enlivening the daily grind.

If you’d like a hand with learning to relax or would like to get fresh insights into why we behave as we do, this course will help. It’s totally secular, practical and takes us all just as we are.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
- Describe some elements of Buddhism through a secular lens
- Describe practical tips to make your meditation time successful
- Practise guided and silent meditation and the importance of ‘noticing how things are’
- Find resources to support you in a long-term, and even life-long, approach to mindfulness
- Describe three elements of the mindfulness revolution in psychology and mental health

Each session includes practical meditation exercises and opportunities for discussion. Bring a notepad and pen.


Duration 4 weeks

Presented by Jan Rivers.

venue: Meow, 9 Edward St, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Deva Mahal is stoked to present her new album Future Classic live to Aotearoa audiences for the first time. Born with the blues in her blood, Deva Mahal blends powerhouse vocals, soul-drenched songwriting, and genre-crossing artistry into a sound uniquely her own. Raised in Hawai’i and musically rooted in New Zealand, she emerged in New York with her debut album RUN DEEP (2018), and has since built an international career spanning sold-out tours, major festivals, and film appearances.

She has graced legendary stages from the Hollywood Bowl and Carnegie Hall to Bonnaroo and the Montreal Jazz Festival, appeared in David O. Russell’s American Hustle, and contributed to the soundtrack of The Experimenter. A three-time APRA Silver Scroll finalist and A2IM Indie Award nominee, and performed at the 2021 Biden-Harris Inauguration. She also featured and wrote on Ledisi’s Grammy-winning THE WILD CARD; contributed vocals to the new Kojey Radical album.

id: Bach Choir of Wellington presents French Impressions-St Mary of the Angels, 17 Boulcott St, Te Aro, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Bach Choir of Wellington presents French Impressions
venue: St Mary of the Angels, 17 Boulcott St, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Join us for French Impressions, an exciting programme of French Romantic choral music. This concert features Louis Vierne’s Messe Solennelle, Op.16 and Gabriel Fauré’s Requiem, Op. 48, two deeply expressive works that embody the boldness and tenderness of these masters’ compositional styles.

The Bach Choir of Wellington welcomes soprano Rowena Simpson and baritone Joe Haddow, with Douglas Mews (organ), to bring these luminous works to life in the resonant acoustic of St Mary of the Angels.

Vierne originally envisioned his Messe Solennelle to be accompanied by orchestra, but his teacher, Charles-Marie Widor, advised him to use two organs (for practical reasons). Written while Vierne was organist at Notre-Dame de Paris, the work showcases his mastery of harmony with moments of both solemnity and radiant joy.

Fauré’s Requiem is a beautiful contrast to Vierne’s mass, offering a more intimate and consoling vision of the afterlife. Though, when asked why he composed it, he declared, “my Requiem wasn’t written for anything – for pleasure, if I may call it that!” Beloved for its gentle melodies and serenity, the Requiem reflects Fauré’s belief in eternal rest and peace.

We invite you to experience this afternoon of majestic and introspective French choral music.

id: Writers on Mondays: Michelle Duff and Saraid de Silva-Te Marae, Te Papa Tongarewa, 55 Cable Street, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Writers on Mondays: Michelle Duff and Saraid de Silva
venue: Te Marae, Te Papa Tongarewa, 55 Cable Street, Wellington
description:
Two writers exploring women’s lives across different landscapes and generations come together in this special event. Award-winning journalist Michelle Duff’s sharp, eclectic short story collection Surplus Women moves nimbly between realism and comic overdrive, meditating on power, patriarchy, and bad decisions. Saraid de Silva’s powerful debut novel, Amma, longlisted for the Women’s Prize for Fiction, follows three women on different paths against shifting cultural backdrops in Singapore, New Zealand, and London. See these writers in conversation with Tina Makereti as they discuss the stories that define us.

id: Sea Glass Rings - One Day Jewellery Making Workshop-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Sea Glass Rings - One Day Jewellery Making Workshop
venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
description:
Design and create a unique ring with foraged sea glass ‘gems’ while learning and developing core jewellery fabrication techniques. An opportunity to engage in creative recycling by turning seaside flotsam into precious wearable treasures. Experiment with ring textures and forms in silver, brass and/or copper, then set your unique glass ‘gemstone’. Finish up with your choice of polish, including high lustre gloss, steel brushed satin, or darkened antique finishes.

If you can, please beachcomb and bring along some sea glass options - ideally around 1cm wide, and with a flat back.


Techniques:

- Create a ring with one bezel set foraged sea glass ‘gem’
- Use jeweller’s callipers to measure and prepare metal
- Use jeweller’s saws or snips to cut and shape metal
- Use files and sanding to refine and smooth metal edges and surfaces
- Use jeweller’s flame torches to solder join metal pieces
- Use Dremel & bench polishers to refine & finish metal casts into wearable jewellery

Project : 1 Ring with sea glass (silver, brass and copper options)
Materials: Sea Glass, Copper, Brass, Sterling Silver

One hour lunch - bring a packed lunch to have in our historic home or explore the local cafes in Te Aro.

Daylong workshop options on either Sunday 20 July or Sunday 24 August.

id: Jazz Orchestra Composer Series Presents: Callum Passells-Bedlam and Squalor, Upstairs, 18 Garrett Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Jazz Orchestra Composer Series Presents: Callum Passells
venue: Bedlam and Squalor, Upstairs, 18 Garrett Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
The seventh concert in our series is a new suite of music by Tāmaki Makaurau composer, performer, and educator; Callum Passells.

For the Jazz Orchestra Composer Series Callum brings new music for his ensemble LCR, an ensemble which features three identical saxophone trios (sax, bass, and drums) that play with and against each other in a kaleidoscopic and often explosive fashion. The new pieces commissioned for this series continue to stretch at the fabric of jazz and improvised forms, and are inspired by Morton Feldman, Lennie Tristano, Henry Threadgill and Sly Stone.

Callum has been deeply involved in the New Zealand jazz and improvised music scene for over a decade, and is a busy freelancer in the wider music community in Auckland. He has performed with Aldous Harding, Hans Pucket, the Exploding Rainbow Orchestra, the Auckland Philharmonia Orchestra, among many others. In 2021, Callum was commissioned to compose a large-scale work 'Solid Spirit, Liquid Body' for the Wellington Jazz Festival. He is currently completing a Master of Music degree at the University of Auckland, where he also teaches saxophone.

The Jazz Orchestra Composer Series showcases original music for large jazz ensemble by New Zealand composers. Concerts take place every 1st and 3rd Friday of the month, from May to October, from 7pm. Tickets are $15, door sales $20.

id: Snowfall On Main - with FreshChoice Greytown-Greytown Town Hall, 89 Main St, Greytown-Event Finder
name: Snowfall On Main - with FreshChoice Greytown
venue: Greytown Town Hall, 89 Main St, Greytown
description:
Glorious snow will be flurrying once again outside the Town Hall, thanks to FreshChoice Greytown. In what has become a firm festival favourite, this snowfall will be on time, every time, on Friday and Saturday night's throughout the festival. Who knew the forecast could be so accurate!

Set to music and lights, get a taste of a northern hemisphere White Christmas right here in NZ, and enjoy this magical selfie experience! Grab a bite to eat from the range of food trucks on offer, keep your eyes peeled for Hari and his fellow pups, and prepare for a dusting of snow.

Special thanks to the weather gods, who tell us that snow will be falling every half hour from 6pm until 8pm.

id: Night Photography: In the Dark-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Night Photography: In the Dark
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Night photography is, by its nature, magical. In the photographer’s hands, the camera becomes a magic box that allows the night to be caught in a way the human eye could never see.

This course gives you the opportunity to explore and sharpen both your technical and creative skills, so you have the ability and vision to capture the enchanting world that resides in the darkness.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
- Identify the equipment needed to make photographs at night
- Identify how to use technical photographic tools in a nighttime context
- Explore techniques that allow you to develop a more creative approach to picture-making including: light painting, intentional camera movement, light trails and working with water and reflections in your images
- Recognise the importance of light and colour in night photography and develop your ability to use it to make dynamic images

You must bring a tripod and, if you have one, a neutral density filter and cable release remote. You need a fully manual DSLR or mirrorless camera and an intermediate understanding of camera functions. Not suitable for point and shoot cameras.


8 weeks, 7:30 PM -9:30PM
Wellington High School
Presented by David Jensen
$159 incl. GST

name: Twisted Rings for Winter
venue: Workspace Ōtaki, 6 Hewson Crescent, Ōtaki
description:
Craft an elegant twisted silver ring from solid silver!

Learn to soften and twist wire to create the twist you want, then how to form it up into a ring that fits you. Learn to use the jeweller's torch to solder then clean up and polish the ring to a beautiful finish.

This 3-hour class is ideal for beginners, groups of friends and visitors to the city.

An excellent, fun class if you have already taken one of our Stacking Rings or Textured Earrings classes and fancy adding to your jewellery collection.

Included in the class fee are copper and brass for practising on, sterling silver bar to create your twist ring and all consumables such as sandpaper, solder and chemicals. Extra metals are available for purchase in the studio.

id: Niko Ne Zna Live-Vogelmorn Hall, 11 Vennell Street, Brooklyn, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Niko Ne Zna Live
venue: Vogelmorn Hall, 11 Vennell Street, Brooklyn, Wellington
description:
Wellington, get ready! It’s been a minute!

Fresh off a sold-out show in Auckland, Niko Ne Zna returns to the capital for a night of explosive Balkan brass at Vogelmorn Hall.

Expect bold brass, infectious rhythms, soaring vocals, and a dancefloor that won’t quit. This nine-piece powerhouse delivers their signature high-energy performance — featuring brand new songs in preparation for their upcoming third studio album, as well as all the hits you know and love.

Live Balkan brass music

Delicious food available

Cash bar featuring local beers from Kererū Brewing, as well as wine and spirits from the Balkans

A party like no other

With trumpets, saxophone, trombones, sousaphone, tapan (bass drum), snare drum, percussion, and vocals in multiple languages, Niko Ne Zna blends hypnotic melodies, driving rhythms, and theatrical flair into an unforgettable live experience. Whether on the street, in a club, or on a festival stage, their shows are part gig, part spectacle — all heart.

They’ve wowed crowds at WOMAD, featured in What We Do In The Shadows, and played to packed houses across New Zealand and Australia.

Come early, grab a bite, enjoy a Kererū brew, and be part of something special.

Doors at 6pm.

“It’s like being dropped into the hot and spicy lands of a faraway country.” — wellingtonlivemusic.com

“Straight to the dancefloor.” — Elsewhere

“Driving rhythms, an intoxicating effect.” — Taranaki Daily News

www.nikonezna.com

id: The Joy of Improvisation-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: The Joy of Improvisation
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Discover your creative potential and enjoy improvising scenes and stories in a safe, positive group environment with the Wellington Improvisation Troupe [WIT].

Description
Improv is theatre without a script and a fun way to build your skills in many areas, including team work, public speaking, storytelling and on-your-feet creative thinking.

This is the perfect place for absolute beginners to get acquainted with the joy and art of improvisation, inspired by the generous creative philosophy of Keith Johnstone. It's also a great place to get back into improv if you've been away from it for a while.

WIT has been teaching this course in association with the CEC for almost 20 years now. It uses fun games and structured exercises to teach the foundation skills of improv. These are a prerequisite for further courses and membership of WIT (www.wit.org.nz), as well as useful in themselves.

If you have questions about the course, please contact WIT directly on info@wit.org.nz.

By the end of the course, you'll have:

- Explored basic principles of improvisation
- Enjoyed interacting in a friendly, positive and supportive environment
- Developed more confidence, presentation and communication skills
- Experienced joyful moments of improvisation

The course will end with a directed demonstration of class exercises for invited friends and family.

[This is a physical activity that involves an element of risk. While all possible measures are taken to prevent accidents or injury, please note that participation is at your own risk].

id: Mrs Floss' Winter Sip & Scribble Cafe-Greytown Distilling Co - Judgement Room, Level 2, 110 Main Street, Greytown, Greytown-Event Finder
name: Mrs Floss' Winter Sip & Scribble Cafe
venue: Greytown Distilling Co - Judgement Room, Level 2, 110 Main Street, Greytown, Greytown
description:
THIS EVENT HAS SOLD OUT. Are you after another great Village bookshop event? Check out "Cross Stitch Bookmarks with Mrs Blackwell"
When asked to imagine her perfect cafe, Mrs Floss dreamed of a magical place called The Sip & Scribble. A cafe where you can sit quietly with your journals and your thoughts, surrounded by your fellow travellers.

Where you can sketch, write with your favourite pen, put together pages of your junk journal, or write yourself dreamy lists of places to visit and books to read. It’s a cafe where no one will frown upon your sprawled collection of art supplies or suggest that you're taking up too much space.

Where they deliver sweet treats and bottomless coffee and tea.

Mrs Floss' vision came to life for a sell-out session in February, and we’re bringing it back for one perfect Sunday afternoon session this July!

Your ticket includes:
An ephemera pack containing high-quality papers, stickers, vintage postage stamps and a few other surprises for decorating your journal pages
A generous selection of sweet treats (vegan and gluten-free available)
A bottomless range of teas and filter coffee
Fine company and a morning relaxing with like-minded journal enthusiasts - you bring your own journals and your favourite supplies, all journals and types of journalling are welcome at this event.

We’ll have all the basics like pens, pencils, glue, tape, scissors and some stickers available for you to use.
Extra journalling supplies and stickers will be for sale on the day

Both Mrs Floss and Mrs Blackwell will be on hand if you’d like to ask us any questions, or for help and inspiration.

Suitable for seasoned journallers, as well as those just about getting started.
Accessibility: This event is being held at the Greytown Distilling Company Judgement Room, Level 2, 110 Main Street (upstairs from Blackwell & Sons). Access is by one flight of stairs.

id: Pelvic Power Workshop-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Pelvic Power Workshop
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Pelvic floor muscles become weakened, often after childbirth, and can cause incontinence, constipation or frequent urination. These Feldenkrais Method® techniques will help you regain muscle efficiency and tone. For women only.

Description
Apart from assisting with supporting internal organs, and controlling elimination, the pelvic floor is an important part of a woman's overall stability and posture, so you will gain improvement in this respect as well. You'll learn far more than conventional pelvic floor strengthening.

You'll learn to differentiate different parts of the pelvic floor, and also how the pelvic floor functions in conjunction with breathing and spinal movements.

By the end of the workshop, you’ll be able to:
-Recognise the anatomy of the pelvic floor, where the muscles are and how they work
- Coordinate the pelvic floor muscles with breathing, and with the spine, and recognise its role in overall good posture
- Discover what habits you have which work against your pelvic floor muscles working well
- Practise exercises designed to help you rehabilitate and strengthen your pelvic floor

Please note that instructions are given verbally rather than by demonstration, so good hearing and understanding of English is required. For women only.

id: The Superjesus - Aotearoa New Zealand Tour With the After-Meow, 9 Edward St, Te Aro, Wellington-Event Finder
name: The Superjesus - Aotearoa New Zealand Tour With the After
venue: Meow, 9 Edward St, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
THE SUPERJESUS - A long career in the music industry is much of a rarity these days but Adelaide rockers The Superjesus have managed to hold their place as one of Australia’s most respected live bands for almost 30 years.

Emerging in the late 90’s and signing to Warners worldwide they released 3 classic albums, Sumo, Jet Age and Rock Music, two of which went platinum. The 3 x Aria award winners took a hiatus in the mid 2000’s to work on solo projects and re-emerged in 2013 to test the waters. Pleased to have found themselves well received by the public they headed back into the studio for 2016’s EP Love And Violence followed by a double live album.

The South Australian Music Hall Of Fame inductees have a strong work ethic and an ear for a good hook. With hits such as ‘Gravity’ , ‘Secret Agent Man’, ‘Down Again’ & ‘Now And Then’ under their belt their songwriting has always remained their strong point. It has been 20 years since The Superjesus have released a full-length album of new music. In 2025 the band released their first self-titled album ‘The Superjesus’. After 30 years of crafting their sound, the songwriting partnership of Sarah McLeod & Stuart Rudd has truly found its sweet spot.

Rudd say’s “our writing partnership together has blossomed into a fantastic place to be creative. McLeod backed this up with “When you find a great creative writing partner, stick with it” From the opening bars of ‘Starlight’ we hear classic TSJ, tipping the hat to the 90’s sound they are known for while surging forward lyrically & melodically to create something really special.

This is the new Superjesus, a more soulful engaging version of the band we know and love where song writing is king. To date 5 singles have been released from the forthcoming self-titled album “Money (We’re Only In It For Love), ‘Lights Out’, ‘We Won’t Let Go Until It’s Over’, ‘Something Good’ & a cover of Generation X’s ‘Dancing With Myself’. All 5 singles have gained national airplay, setting the mood for this highly anticipated release.

They have kept the beautiful ballad ‘Diamonds’ to accompany the release. Here we see The Superjesus like never before, a beautiful emotive stirrer written on the piano showcasing how far the band has come musically, coupled with Sarah McLeod's classic rich vocals. The Superjesus are back stronger than ever and according to Rudd “not going anywhere anytime soon” . McLeod said “For us the magic is in the creation of the music & as a band we have found this process very soul enriching, I truly feel it’s our best work yet, I love every song on this record ”.

Supporting TSJ on the NZ shows is NZ’s THE AFTER.
The After are a pop/rock band blending moody grooves, gritty guitars & soaring melodies into emotionally charged soundscapes. Already two massive Asia Pacific tours under their belt, a string of NZ tours, significant airplay & video successes; The After are a well-oiled live act with a fast-growing international reputation. At the helm is the magnetic Ruby Fraser, whose powerhouse vocals and searing guitar work channel raw emotion & rebellious spirit. Founding member Andrew Featherstone lays the groundwork on bass with tight, tasteful songwriting. Behind the kit, Gareth Scott delivers versatile, thunderous rhythms, while Bruce Madden—a true Hammond organ virtuoso—elevates the band’s sound with lush swells & soul-soaked textures rarely heard in modern pop/rock.

Singles co-produced & mixed by Steve James (Screaming Jets, Sex Pistols), latest track “Mesmerised” mastered by Leon Zervos (INXS, AC/DC, Pink). • ‘Mesmerised’ radio & TV in NZ & the Philippines • ‘Clear to Me’ (feat. Split Enz legend Eddie Rayner) the most-played rock track NZ’s Juice TV in 2021, airing on 500 stations worldwide.• ‘Doesn’t Matter’ Radioscope Top 40 & a JUICE TV staple. • ‘Where There’s a Will, There’s a Way’ 600k views, video shot in Tokyo, Manila, Hong Kong, Singapore, & Auckland. • cover of Filipino band Dilaw’s hit “Uhaw” 500k views.

id: The Royal New Zealand Ballet - Home, Land and Sea-St James Theatre, 77-87 Courtenay Place, Wellington-Event Finder
name: The Royal New Zealand Ballet - Home, Land and Sea
venue: St James Theatre, 77-87 Courtenay Place, Wellington
description:
Home, Land and Sea presents three ballets inspired by journeys in unknown seas, and what it means to come home.

Moss Te Ururangi Patterson’s new work, Home, Land and Sea, created for six dancers from the RNZB and six from The New Zealand Dance Company.

Moss’s work weaves the cultural heritage of Aotearoa New Zealand with historical echoes of Cook’s Endeavour voyages. Drawing inspiration from early European perceptions of this land, Moss integrates the haunting melodies of taonga pūoro—traditional Māori instruments—into a dynamic and poetic performance. Audiences are invited to embark on a reflective journey through time, exploring how shared history shapes present and influences our path forward.

Shaun James Kelly will create a new work titled Chrysalis, inspired by his metamorphosis from young dancer in Scotland to Soloist and Choreographer in Residence in New Zealand.

Stephen Baynes’s The Way Alone A deeply personal response to music by Tchaikovsky completes the programme.

id: Planting and Track Maintenance - Working Bee-Manawa Karioi Reserve, Danube Street, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Planting and Track Maintenance - Working Bee
venue: Manawa Karioi Reserve, Danube Street, Wellington
description:
Our track maintenance and planting working bees are focussing on plant species diversity rather than large planting quantities. We have ordered 500 special trees from the Berhampore Nursery. We are in this for the long haul and a forest that contains a wide range of plant species will, in turn, attract a wider range of birds, lizards, and invertebrates. A wider range of plant species also allows for the forest to naturally regenerate and helps prevent weed species from establishing.

Tools are provided, bring sturdy shoes and a water bottle, Working bees are held every Sunday in June (except June 1st - Kings Birthday Weekend) and August 2025.

Meeting at the Information Shelter in the Tapu te Ranga car park at the end of Danube Street in Island Bay. Children are welcome with parents or guardians.

id: Anyone Can Draw - Structural-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Anyone Can Draw - Structural
venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
description:
In this course you will examine structural drawing with a careful helpful approach, focusing on simple perspective drawing and the value of geometric shapes and solids. Both these structural approaches contribute greatly to the success of your drawing.

Geometric shapes can simplifying a subject, unify a drawing and make compositions dynamic. Geometric solids will help render any subject in three dimensions and transition to perspective.

A good working knowledge of the concepts of perspective will help you draw any subject with correct dimensionality. It can also help in your realist drawing, painting and invented subjects and environments. These concepts are also used in most two dimensional art because it enables us to realise great spatial effects, making it an invaluable tool to add to your skill set.

In this course you will learn the following:

- Focus on geometric shapes and solids and how they contribute to both realist and abstract drawing
- Form an appreciation of geometry and shapes that can help with constructing a drawing
- The important tools, methods and concepts of one-point, two-point and three-point perspective
- Universal boxing, drawing ellipses
- Hints in locating helpful lines and axis to draw real subjects
- Introductory methods of working that blend perspective knowledge with real drawing situations

All basic materials supplied.

Wednesday evenings, 6:30 - 8:30 pm, 23 July - 10 September.
OR
Friday mornings, 10 am - 1 pm, 25 July - 12 September.

description:
Yin Yoga & Sound Healing
Slow yoga, soothing sounds, and a nourishing plant-based meal—a grounding evening from start to finish.

Take a pause from the rush and settle into an evening of deep rest and reconnection. This special session combines the stillness of yin yoga with the soothing power of sound healing—an immersive experience to calm the body and quiet the mind.

Yin yoga is a slow, meditative practice where poses are held for several minutes, allowing the body to open gently and the nervous system to reset. It’s a chance to soften, breathe, and listen inward.

As you rest in each pose, you’ll be surrounded by the gentle sounds of healing frequencies. Sound healing works on a vibrational level—helping to release tension, restore balance, and bring a sense of inner peace.

Guided by Nicola’s thoughtful approach to yin and Nizaad’s calming presence with sound, this evening is a space to simply be—to feel, to unwind, and to receive.
To close the night, we’ll share a nourishing plant-based dinner and dessert—included in your ticket.

All levels welcome.

id: Qi Gong-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Qi Gong
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Qi gong, pronounced “chi gong,” was developed in China thousands of years ago as part of traditional Chinese medicine. It involves using exercises to optimize energy within the body, mind, and spirit, with the goal of improving and maintaining health and well-being.

Qigong has both psychological and physical components and involves the regulation of the mind, breath, and body’s movement and posture.

In most forms of qigong:

Breath is slow, long, and deep. Breath patterns may switch from abdominal breathing to breathing combined with speech sounds.
Movements are typically gentle and smooth, aimed for relaxation.
Mind regulation includes focusing one’s attention and visualization.
Dynamic (active) qigong techniques primarily focus on body movements, especially movements of the whole body or arms and legs. Meditative (passive) qigong techniques can be practiced in any posture that can be maintained over time and involve breath and mind exercises, with almost no body movement.
Wear loose, comfortable clothing and bring a bottle of water.

[This is a physical activity that involves an element of risk. While all possible measures are taken to prevent accidents or injury, please note that participation is at your own risk].

Duration 6 weeks

name: Breathwork: Conscious & Connected
venue: Bhakti Lounge Wellington, 1st Floor, 175 Vivian Street, Wellington
description:
Breathwork: Conscious & Connected
Experience a powerful 1-hour journey designed to calm your mind, regulate your nervous system, and leave you feeling grounded, clear, and deeply refreshed.

Your ticket also includes a delicious plant-based dinner and dessert — the perfect way to nourish your body after this deep, restorative experience.

Led by certified Breathwork Facilitator Hailey (trained in the Sacred Breath Method), this session combines conscious connected breathwork, ceremonial cacao, and a dreamy sound bath for a full-body energetic reset. You’ll be gently guided to quiet the mental noise, connect with your body’s inner wisdom, and access an expanded state of consciousness.

What to Expect:

Opening cacao ceremony (gluten-free & vegan)

Intro to conscious connected breathwork

Guided breath session

Immersive sound bath to integrate the journey

Perfect for beginners and experienced breathers alike—no prior experience needed, just an open mind and curiosity.

What to Bring:

Water bottle

Journal & pen for reflections

Please Note:
This session is not suitable for those in their first trimester of pregnancy or with certain health conditions (e.g., cardiovascular disease, severe asthma, epilepsy). If you’re unsure whether this is right for you, feel free to message us — your safety comes first.



Meet Hailey, your facilitator

Hailey’s journey with Breathwork started five years ago when she realised she felt like a stranger in her own life - living on autopilot, weighed down by stress, stuck in old patterns, and disconnected from what truly mattered.

That first Breathwork session changed everything. It revealed a deep and stable calm beneath the chaos - and she’s been breathing with intention ever since.

Hailey has guided over 65 groups and individuals through powerful and transformational sessions. Her approach blends science-backed techniques with intuitive guidance, helping people shift into balance, presence and empowerment.

When she’s not guiding Breathwork sessions, you’ll likely find her oceanside at sunset, sipping on a coconut matcha, or getting lost in a good book. She’s all about finding little pockets of joy and presence in her everyday life.

Hailey is a Certified Breathwork Facilitator with Sacred Breath Academy: Holistic, Trauma-Informed Breathwork Facilitator Training & Certification Program (400 hours); and a Certified Mindfulness Facilitator with Mindfulness New Zealand.
