id: The Inner Magnet: Attracting Inner Well-Being-Bhakti Lounge Wellington, 1st Floor, 175 Vivian Street, Wellington-Event Finder
name: The Inner Magnet: Attracting Inner Well-Being
venue: Bhakti Lounge Wellington, 1st Floor, 175 Vivian Street, Wellington
description:
Tuesday Wellbeing Seminars

We all seek deeper fulfillment and lasting happiness. In this workshop, discover how to attract the life satisfaction you’ve been craving by tuning into desires that align with your true self. Through practical insights and timeless yoga wisdom, we’ll explore how to create a life based on what truly nourishes you. Join us to unlock the power of your inner magnet and create lasting transformation.

Meet your host, Sivananda

Sivananda’s background is in both science and music, holding a Master's Degree in Data Science, a Bachelor of Science in Physics and a long history of playing and performing on the double bass. His passion for philosophy, music, good food and community attracted him to the bhakti lifestyle. Having studied and practiced the science of the ‘self’ for six years now, he thrives on drawing insights from contemporary science and combining it with yoga wisdom to encourage others to explore new perspectives.

id: Negociants Fine Wine Tour 2025 - Wellington-Te Wharewaka o Poneke, Taranaki St Wharf, Wellington-Event Finder

description:
Established in 1985 and celebrating a 40th Anniversary this year, Negociants New Zealand is a distributor of premium wines from around the world. We are very pleased to present at the 2025 Negociants Fine Wine Tour, a selection of highly regarded, award winning wines from New Zealand and Australia and also to introduce some of the personalities that craft and stand behind these distinctive and fabulous wines.

From New Zealand: Auntsfield, Black Barn, Fromm, Greywacke, Misha's Vineyard, Mt Beautiful, Nautilus, Opawa, Palliser, Pyramid Valley, Rippon, Saint Clair, Smith & Sheth, Two Paddocks

This is an R18 event

id: Albi/Chris Dent & Hannah Morrell-Hilltop, 17 Upland Road, Kelburn, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Albi/Chris Dent & Hannah Morrell
venue: Hilltop, 17 Upland Road, Kelburn, Wellington
description:
Gate opens 6.30pm Music Starts 7pm Saturday 26 July 2025
Auckland based Albi/Chris Dent is an earthy songwriter who keeps both feet on the ground while being expressive and heartfelt in his stories and music.
His appearance is striking as he wields his albinism with pride in the form of a big white beard. His voice too isn’t quite what you’d expect. More smooth, more pronounced, and more powerful than his rough exterior may evoke. Chris grew up in rural New Zealand and likes to tell tales about the little things, as those are what make our lives rich and full. He’s mostly performed with award-winning indie-folk band Albi & The Wolves but has written songs in many different projects, including a collaboration with Mt Eden Dubstep that has amassed over one million streams, or his side project Sneakers which has a single with over 750,000 streams.
Whether it’s on the stage or off Chris is known for his work ethic and as he sets out on a new journey, quietly creating new solo music, he’s excited to see where that leads. For this show, Chris will be joined by the accomplished musician Hannah Morrell on the violin and maybe even the banjo. She is a seasoned touring musician who hails from Tasmania, Australia and has performed with the likes of The Dead Maggies (TAS), Claire Anne Taylor (TAS), Looking For Alaska, Finn Johanson, Holly Arrowsmith, and Jess Bailey (Fables).
Not for profit, supporting our dedicated musicians. Suggested donation $30
Come along and enjoy this gig in our special space, up close and personal.
Teas, Coffee and Snacks provided. You're welcome to bring anything you'd like to eat or drink.
Parking available in the Coupon zones of Upland Rd & Glasgow St free after 6pm weekdays, and free all through the weekends. The Wilson Carpark at the top of the Cable Car charges 24/7.

id: Cooking: Homemade Chinese Egg Noodles And Pan-Fried Buns-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Cooking: Homemade Chinese Egg Noodles And Pan-Fried Buns
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Do you love the taste of fresh egg noodles without additives? Keen to make your own meat buns but unsure where to start? Come and discover how you can easily replicate these delicious specialities at home.

The egg noodles that you will create are great for making simple Asian noodle dishes, or you can top them off with of your favourite sauce. The meat buns you create are soft with succulent and juicy meat filling, perfect for a simple breakfast, lunch, or as a snack.

Some communal ingredients will be supplied but a list of additional ingredients needed will be sent out when course numbers are confirmed. (Approximate cost $35).

Please bring an apron, dish cloth, small rolling pin, sharp knife, tea towels and containers to take food home.

Note: course is not suitable for those who are vegetarian or gluten-free.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
- Make a selection of Chinese egg noodles and buns to take home
- Understand more about the Chinese egg noodle-making process
- Understand more about the Chinese bun-making process
- Feel more confident to make Chinese egg noodles and buns by hand at home

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

Presented by Mei-Fen Sundgren.

id: Test Kitchen Friday's-Luna Estate, Puruatanga Rd, Martinborough-Event Finder
name: Test Kitchen Friday's
venue: Luna Estate, Puruatanga Rd, Martinborough
description:
Introducing Test Kitchen Friday’s
Every other Friday, starting Friday 9th May, all day we will be running our Test Kitchen Menu alongside our regular menu.

Join us on another culinary tour through the diverse continent of Asia. Beginning in the Northern most parts of China heading South through the regions, crossing borders and gastronomic boundaries.

This year we want to relaunch the Test Kitchen Series that was so popular last winter but with a few small, exciting changes that will give you all the chance to get to know us and our team even better through childhood tales and food from our hometowns.

The Test Kitchen Menu will be $55 per person and will consist of 5 dishes, designed and portioned to be shared between two people. Each event will show a variety of different techniques and cuisines all culminating in an ever changing food offering throughout the seasons

The perfect way to kickoff your weekend in Martinborough.

Head to www.lunaestate.co.nz/eclipse to book your table now!

Please note, due to the nature of the Test Kitchen Menu, we may not be able to cater to all dietary restrictions. If you have questions regarding your dietary requirements please call ahead of booking.

id: QTea High Tea-QT Wellington, 90 Cable Street, Wellington-Event Finder
name: QTea High Tea
venue: QT Wellington, 90 Cable Street, Wellington
description:
Clouds of sugar-spun wonder and dollops of cream piled high, QTea is a signature high tea experience that’s not for the quaint-hearted.

Executive Chef Antoine Collets has whipped up the first signature QTea High Tea in Wellington – with an ooh la la French take. Bastille macaron smothered in a caramelised apple, vanilla white chocolate ganache or gorge on gougère, smoked cheese and truffle béchamel. That’s just a taste.

QTea is luxuriantly laid out for leisure lovers, lavish loungers and avant-garde gustos alike. Bring your discerning tastes and daring demeanour and live luxe at QT Wellington.

id: Ngaio Repair Cafe-Ngaio Union Church, 3 Kenya St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Ngaio Repair Cafe
venue: Ngaio Union Church, 3 Kenya St, Wellington
description: Ngaio Repair Café, organised in and by Ngaio Union Church, is part of the worldwide Repair Café movement to cut down waste and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Our local volunteer repairers will look at and try to fix all sorts of household gear: wooden, metal, electrical, electronic, pottery, computer, fabric, toys, clothing, beads, cardboard – as long as it’s small enough for you to bring. One of our volunteers is a guitar repairer who can mend and tune any fretted instruments. Another has an oilstone and will sharpen knives. While you wait to have your item looked at, tea and coffee and cold drink are provided. Children with care-givers are welcome. We have some basic materials on site but if your broken thing needs specific parts (e.g. zip, plug) please bring those along. It’s all free but a gold coin koha is appreciated to help local community need. We open each third Saturday of the month beginning March and finishing November.

id: Tuesday Jewellery-Making in 8 Weeks-Workspace Studios Ltd, 65 Abel Smith St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Tuesday Jewellery-Making in 8 Weeks
venue: Workspace Studios Ltd, 65 Abel Smith St, Wellington
description:
Our popular weeknight classes are the best way for beginners to get into jewellery making in a lively, warm and friendly environment. It starts on Tue 12 August and runs for 8 weeks until Tue 30 September, 5.30-8pm.

Beginners will focus on cabochon stone set ring. The stone setting process teaches you many fundamental techniques in one project!

We start with basic ring making in copper or brass, students will learn measuring, texturing, shaping, cutting and soldering.
Then we move on to making a practice ring set with a cabochon stone (cabochon means it has a flat bottom and a smooth domed top).

Once your first setting is completed you can move to working in silver and produce another stone set ring with more interesting design elements.

Advanced: Chain Making and other projects.

Please see the link on the Regular Classes page for more detail on course content.

Included in the class fee are copper and brass for practising on, up to 8 grams of sterling silver, an extra $8 for stones and fine silver and all consumables such as sandpaper, solder and chemicals. Extra metals and materials are available for purchase in the studio.

venue: St Andrews on the Terrace, 30 The Terrace, Wellington

The Levansa trio played for us in 2022. They are Andrew Beer (violin), Lev Sivkov (cello) and Sarah Watkins (piano). Andrew is Concertmaster for the Auckland Philharmonia but frequently plays chamber music also. Lev is a concerto soloist, recitalist and chamber musician based in Switzerland. A laureate of numerous competitions, he won the Naumburg Competition in New York in 2015. Sarah was a founding member of NZTrio and is a frequent chamber music performer. She has been Classical Artist of the Year along with Andrew Beer.

Rebecca Clarke, Piano Trio (1921)
Salina Fisher, Kintsugi

A Twilight Drag Spectacle – Hosted by Bunny Holiday

Calling all nightwalkers, sparkle vamps, and Forks fanatics – it’s time to sink your teeth into the campiest cult classic tribute of the year!

Join Bunny Holiday, Wellington’s blonde bombshell and the world’s first official drag Playboy Bunny, as she hosts a glitter-soaked, blood-thirsty drag extravaganza inspired by Twilight and its deliciously angsty legacy.

Expect immortal glamour, werewolf thirst traps, iconic quotes, and performances hotter than Edward in the sun. Whether you're Team Edward, Team Jacob, or just Team Messy Bitch Who Loves Drama – this night is for you.

id: Dungeons and Decades: Time Is Just A Number-BATS Theatre, 1 Kent Tce, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Dungeons and Decades: Time Is Just A Number
venue: BATS Theatre, 1 Kent Tce, Wellington
description:
Stop the clocks - you won’t want to miss this adventure through time!

Wellington-based Dungeons and Dragons podcast Last In Initiative is back, and this time not even the clock can contain us.

Mark it in your calendars, get the date right, and be at BATS for three timeless tales, guaranteed to take you on a comedy-packed, action-filled romp across time, space, and most importantly, the 80’s.

Join our players as they spark a Fantasy French Revolution in 1789, rob a speeding train in 1886, and get minimum wage jobs at an arcade in 1982.

Each night brings new adventure, new challenges, and most importantly, a new decade.

So join our four time travellers as they stumble their way across all of the 80s.

Or at least three of them.

This show follows the success of 'Dungeons and Delinquents: Be Gay Do Crime' and 'Dungeons and Da Vinci: The One With Art', shows that had TTRPG nerds and novices alike laughing along.

Now 'Dungeons and Decades' promises to be a game equally full of hijinks, and with time puns so consistent you can set your watch by them.

id: DADS Army-The Undercurrent, 118 Tory Street, Wellington-Event Finder

DADS is New Zealand’s premier exponent of authentic 1920s dance Jazz. Featuring Rags, Rambles, Shuffles, Drags and Blues that our great grandparents would have shimmied to in the juke joints, speakeasies, woolsheds and Memorial Halls of 1920s New Zealand.

Don’t miss out on this stellar line-up!

Doors at 7pm - Gig at 7:30pm

Tickets available at the door and online!

Wine/beer/hot drinks/snacks and books available as always ;)
We can't wait to dance alongside you!

#wellington #wellingtonmusic #nzjazz

id: Dark Sky Business Capability Course – Wairarapa Edition-Masterton District Council, 64 Chapel St, Masterton-Event Finder
name: Dark Sky Business Capability Course – Wairarapa Edition
venue: Masterton District Council, 64 Chapel St, Masterton
description:
Some nights stay with you forever.
A breeze.
A hush.
A sky so full of stars it silences even the noisiest thoughts. Now imagine making it possible for someone else to feel like that.


Learn how to build a science-based, unforgettable stargazing experience for your business. Join the Dark Sky Business Capabilities course!


We are Hari and Sam, and we already run a very successful stargazing business, Star Safari. And if you think of running one too or just incorporating stargazing into your current business, come and learn from our experience. We want people to come to our region again and again to take in the night sky and learn how to look after it. There is space for everyone in this business, but it takes more than just pointing a laser at the stars to navigate the night sky. We know exactly what it takes. Astrotourism is a fantastic opportunity for everyone in Wairarapa, as we have this fantastic International Dark Sky Reserve at our doorstep.

In this course, you’ll learn how to:
- Integrate stargazing into your existing business
- Design unforgettable dark sky experiences
- Use storytelling and science to engage your visitors
- Navigate dark sky regulations, gear, and location logistics

This is a practical, hands-on workshop designed for tourism operators, educators, accommodation providers, and anyone interested in astro-tourism.

Who Should Attend?
- Tourism operators
- Experience-based businesses
- Eco-lodges / glamping / off-grid retreats
- Educators and guides
- Anyone

Why Join?
- Learn from trusted science communicators
- Gain real-world business insights
- Build a credible, high-quality stargazing offer
- Join a growing national network of dark sky professionals

Supported By:
- WellingtonNZ (Course Sponsor)
- Masterton District Council

id: Ngā Tūrua Kiwi Play Space for Under 5s-Capital E, 4 Queens Wharf, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Ngā Tūrua Kiwi Play Space for Under 5s
venue: Capital E, 4 Queens Wharf, Wellington
description:
Sniff, scratch and burrow at Ngā Turua Kiwi, Kiwi Burrows.

In our latest play activation, whānau can explore themes of creating homes, a connection to whenua, and the importance of conservation in Pōneke.

Imagine yourself as a Western Brown Kiwi as you:
- Wriggle and crawl through kiwi burrows of different shapes and sizes.
- Discover hidden surprises on the forest floor, including crunchy textures, a bouncy seat, and even pests hiding amongst the leaf litter.
- Climb the towering tree to the top of the forest canopy, then slide all the way down to the forest floor.
- Get creative and build your own cozy tūrua burrow using ‘raw’ materials (wheelchair-accessible).

There will be something for every age and accessibility-level, with both high-energy and low-energy play options, a pēpē baby area, and wheelchair-accessible play stations.

This activation is supported by Capital Kiwi Project.

PlayHQ is Nōku te Ao Capital E’s public indoor play space for tamariki aged 0-5.

Open Monday-Saturday, 9.30am-3.30pm.

Ngā Tūrua Kiwi will be our final PlayHQ activation at Queens Wharf, before we move to Te Matapihi ki te Ao Nui, the new Central Library.

Nōku te Ao Capital E is located at 4 Queens Wharf, Wellington. No bookings required, donations appreciated.

id: Alexia Urban Winery Presents: Fondue Chalet-Alexia Urban Winery, 197 West Street, Greytown-Event Finder
name: Alexia Urban Winery Presents: Fondue Chalet
venue: Alexia Urban Winery, 197 West Street, Greytown
description:
Yodelayheehoo! We’re bringing the Alps to Alexia transforming our little urban winery into a cosy Swiss chalet to host (possibly) the world’s smallest wine and fondue festival!

Why travel to Geneva when you can travel to Greytown for an authentic après-ski wine and fondue session, without the bother of skiing…or the snow. It’s guaranteed to be fun though!
Our Grüner Veltliner based cheese fondue is the star of the show – with plenty of bread to dip of course! We’ll be serving up these little hot pots of happiness alongside some other hot cheese delights, Toblerone cremè doughnuts and the Alexia wine list.
Who needs the Matterhorn, Mont Blanc and white outs when there’s mountains of cheese, Blanc de Blancs and White Pinot?

It's wine and fondue like never before, so dust off those ski-jackets, clip on those crampons and get to Alexia!

Pay on consumption.

id: Sculpture - Intro to Creature Sculpting-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Sculpture - Intro to Creature Sculpting
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Join us in an exciting new introduction to creative sculpting - a hands on class to produce unique creature figurines and miniatures to bring your imagination to life! - Beginners welcome! All material costs included in course fee.

Description
Whether you want to make creatures cute, creepy, in the style of pop-toys, figurines, or a one-of-a-kind character in your own style, this is the class for you!

Working with air dry clays, oven bake polymer clays and wire, armatures this workshop offers a variety of modelling methods and approaches - a great opportunity to turn ideas into tangible 3D forms. With modern clays we can create translucent, flexible, and even glow-in-the-dark elements to add more realism or a touch of the surreal into each creation!

We’ll kick off working with traditional air-dry clay to get a feel for modelling a few simple forms.

Once familiar with the materials, we’ll go through some basic design elements, guided by animal anatomy and morphology. From here the tutor will show and chat with the group about ways we can transform the creatures from our imagination into unique sculptures full of character.

Students will be coached through designing and creating a series of small-scale creature sculptures, beginning simple, and building to a more complex final form as we gather practice.

The class offers beginner students a fun introduction to sculpting organic forms from scratch, and for those with some hands-on creative experience, it offers a great opportunity to experiment, hone and advance your making skills to new levels.

Please wear closed-in footwear suitable for a workshop environment. bring a work apron if you have one or wear clothes you don’t mind getting a little grubby. Remember to bring your reading glasses if a have them.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

id: Last Night of the Proms-Whirinaki Whare Taonga, 836 Fergusson Drive, Upper Hutt-Event Finder
name: Last Night of the Proms
venue: Whirinaki Whare Taonga, 836 Fergusson Drive, Upper Hutt
description:
Upper Hutt Brass Band presents Last Night of the Proms — a spectacular evening that blends the beloved traditions of London’s Royal Albert Hall with a distinctive New Zealand flavour. Joining the celebration are The Hutt Valley Singers, alongside a host of talented local artists and soloists. Raise your voice and wave your flag as you revel in stirring favourites like Jerusalem, Land of Hope and Glory, Sea Songs, and rousing patriotic marches — timeless highlights that capture the true spirit of this grand musical tradition.
There are 2 shows: matinee (2pm) and evening show (7pm).

id: Jazz Orchestra Composer Series Presents: Dave Wilson-Bedlam and Squalor, Upstairs, 18 Garrett Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Jazz Orchestra Composer Series Presents: Dave Wilson
venue: Bedlam and Squalor, Upstairs, 18 Garrett Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
The next concert in our series presents a new project by Dave Wilson titled Free, Free: Meditations on Liberation. This project brings together a collective of musicians from across the music communities of Pōneke in an invitation to explore the expansive possibilities for what liberation might sound like.

Free, Free draws from legacies of musical collectivity, and celebrates a commitment to both collaboration and the distinct expression of each individual.

Ranging from contemplative minimalism to ecstatic ensemble energy and body-moving grooves, the music of Free, Free invites musicians and other listeners to tend to each moment, making their own offerings to shape the collective sound.

Dave Wilson is a saxophonist, clarinettist, composer, producer, and interdisciplinary scholar. His music bridges avant-garde and experimental music with various groove-oriented styles from the worlds of jazz, R&B, electronic music, and more. With his 2023 album Ephemeral, described as “quite spiritually intense music” by The Guardian, he was a finalist for Te Manu Taki Tautito o te Tau | Best Jazz Artist at the Aotearoa Music Awards, and for the APRA Best Jazz Composition Award. Before relocating to Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington in 2016, Dave grew up in the Chicago area, lived for a decade in Los Angeles, and spent several stints living in Skopje, North Macedonia.

Free, Free: Meditations on Liberation:
Dave Wilson, Tyaan Singh – alto saxophone
Louisa Williamson – tenor saxophone
Monique Lapins, Mana Waiariki – violin
Ken Ichinose – cello
Kaito Walley, Natania Ngawhau – trombone
Ben Hunt – trumpet
Daniel Hayles, Andrew Faleatua – piano and keyboard
Phoebe Johnson – bass
Callum Allardice – guitar
Hikurangi Schaverien-Kaa – drums

The performance will begin with an opening set by Flute Journeys, an offbeat mass flute ensemble with the self-described playing abilities of 5–12-year-olds, embodying a form of liberation in music.

The Jazz Orchestra Composer Series showcases original music for large jazz ensemble by New Zealand composers. Concerts take place every 1st and 3rd Friday of the month, from May to October, from 7pm. Tickets are $15 from Humanitix, door sales $20.

Thanks to CNZ for their generous support. See less

id: Book Launch: Lofty – The Short Life of Lieutenant Frank Long DFC-Hedleys Bookshop, 150 Queen St, Masterton-Event Finder
name: Book Launch: Lofty – The Short Life of Lieutenant Frank Long DFC
venue: Hedleys Bookshop, 150 Queen St, Masterton
description:
Rick Long invites you to the launch of Lofty: The Short Life of Flight Lieutenant Frank Long DFC, the story of a wartime hero from Masterton, written by local historian, Neil Frances.

In December 1937, 21 year old Masterton man Frank Long joined the Royal Air Force and was flying Whitley Bombers over Nazi Germany shortly after.

For 18 months Frank took part in the RAF’s early bombing campaign against Germany – a time of trial and many errors as the British Empire fought with its back to the wall against an aggressive and triumphant foe.

Drawing on family records, letters and photographs, and a wide range of wartime and official records, author and military historian Neil Frances brings a decorated Masterton pilot to life 80 years after his death in action.

The launch will include a short talk and be followed by a book signing with Rick Long and Neil Frances. The book, Lofty, will be available to purchase on the day.

All are welcome at this free celebratory event, but please RSVP to Hedley’s Books, Masterton on sales@hedleysbooks.co.nz, 06 378 2875 or text 027 281 6421

id: Daily Keyno And Warm Regards-Valhalla, 154 Vivian Street, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Daily Keyno And Warm Regards
venue: Valhalla, 154 Vivian Street, Wellington
description:
Daily Keyno & Warm Regards

Daily Keyno, the brain child of Mark Sommerville, is proud to announce the release of their debut album, That’s my jc, available on all major streaming platforms starting September 25th..

That’s my jc is a personal project, featuring 8 tracks that explore themes of love, loneliness, fatherhood, past reflections. The album showcases Daily Keyno’s signature spacious, crystal like guitar, while pushing into new sonic territory.

Lead singles like Sunlight. Sugar and Peaches & Creme have already garnered critical acclaim, with Sunlight. Sugar was praised by Glen Thurston of Music, Movies & Madness as A lot of fun, a dreamy musical experience. The album also features the slick rhythm section of Riki Gooch, Jacqui Nyman, and Dayle Jellyman

This album is a reflection of where I am creatively and emotionally right now, says Sommerville. I wanted to make something sincere and sonically simple/minimal.

Leading up to the release, Daily Keyno will be performing -
July 16th - Valhalla, Te Whanganui a tara

Tracklist for That’s my jc:
1. Ocean Blue
2. My beautifully sad walk home
3. Birth
4. Days drag
5. My love is shining
6. Sunlight. Sugar
7. Dayle on the record
8. Peaches & Creme

Warm Regards are a Te Whanganui-a-Tara based country dream-rock band.
They are great mates, and have over 150 years of experience playing in bands and being human beings.
They are super pumped to be playing with their friends Daily Keyno at Valhalla - it’s going to be a great night!!
They recently released this song. Listen to it!!

id: The Ballad of Maria Marten-Te Raukura ki Kapiti, Sir Jon Trimmer Theatre, 34a Raumati Rd, Paraparaumu-Event Finder
name: The Ballad of Maria Marten
venue: Te Raukura ki Kapiti, Sir Jon Trimmer Theatre, 34a Raumati Rd, Paraparaumu
description:
Maven Theatre Company, in partnership with Te Raukura ki Kapiti, proudly presents the New Zealand premiere of The Ballad of Maria Marten, an innovative reimagining of the infamous ‘Red Barn Murder’ of 1827.

Maven’s inaugural offering, The Ballad of Maria Marten explores the notorious ‘Red Barn Murder’ of 1827 which has become a part of British folklore and the subject of sensational gossip and grim speculation. A young woman named Maria Marten went to a barn in Suffolk to meet her lover with plans to elope. A year later, her body was discovered hidden beneath the floor. What is the truth behind her murder? Why was she killed? And who was responsible?

Rather than providing a literal retelling of this historic true crime, the play offers a thrilling reappraisal that focuses on Maria’s life. It celebrates the solidarity among female friendships and highlights the stark realities that young working -class women in rural areas faced, including limited choices due to their gender, social class, and lack of education. Through a mix of storytelling, dance, and humor, Maria's fate is explored through the eyes of the women who loved her, illuminating a complex narrative of love, loss, prejudice, and patriarchal power.

Join us for this thrilling New Zealand premiere, where historical crime meets contemporary theatre, and Maria Marten’s story is told through the eyes of the women who loved her.

Maven is the newest theatre company on the Kapiti Coast and was born from a passion for bold storytelling and a commitment to creating immersive, thought-provoking theatre that challenges conventions. Maven was formed by Sera Devcich and Jessica Clough, the creative team behind the extended sold-out season of Nick Dear’s Frankenstein on the Kapiti Coast last year. That production received numerous accolades at the Wellington District Theatre Federation Awards, including Best Drama and Best Overall - a first for any production from Kapiti. The overwhelming feedback received from patrons was a desire to see more locally produced, ambitious, meaningful, and expertly crafted theatre. And so, Maven was established.

Content Advisory: This play contains adult themes and some content that may disturb. Recommended for audiences 16+

--

For accessibility seating information and wheelchair space bookings please email kiaora@teraukura.nz or call 04)9740535 during office hours.

id: Ōtari Raranga Weavers 2025 Post Matariki Season - Beginners-Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush, 160 Wilton Road, Wilton, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Ōtari Raranga Weavers 2025 Post Matariki Season - Beginners
venue: Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush, 160 Wilton Road, Wilton, Wellington
description:
Kua raranga tahi tātou he whariki mō āpōpō
Together we weave the mat for future generations

Nau mai haere mai, all are welcome to attend Ōtari Raranga wānanga (classes).

No experience required and all materials provided. You will walk away with woven taonga at the end of every class.

Over 3-4 classes beginner students should complete a variety of putiputi (flowers), a kōnae (2 corner kete - basket), and a kono (4 sided kete). After completing 4 beginner classes (close together) you may have the skills to move up to our intermediate classes. Please talk with our kaiako and kaiāwhina if this is something you aspire to.

With regular attendance you will:
- Learn tikanga (protocols) and karakia for hauhake (harvesting) and preparing harakeke
- Build your mātauranga (knowledge)
- Use kupu Māori appropriate to raranga practice
- Develop your pūkenga (practical skills)
- Create taonga (treasures) for your whānau
- Build hononga (connections) within our raranga rōpū (group)
- Have the skills to practice at home.

What’s included in your beginners ticket?
- Three hour weaving class with experienced kaiako
- Access to tools and harakeke
- Harakeke is provided for your first two classes and then the tikanga is that you should hauhake (harvest) for yourself.
- If you are unable to harvest for class, we have a $20 ‘Please harvest for me’ option in addition to your ticket at least two days before class.
- Light refreshments are provided and we encourage you to bring kai to share

Led by Linda Lee (Ngāti Huia, Ngāti Raukawa, Ngāti Kurī, Te Rarawa, Te Aupōuri), and Anna Lees (Te Āti Awa, Kāi Tahu), and on occasion our raranga rangatira; Frank Topia (Ngā Puhi, Ngāti Porou, Ngāti Haua), with support from our kaiāwhina; Anita Murdoch (Ngati Kahungunu, Waikato-Tainui), Sarah O’Sullivan (Ngāi Tahu), Te Kāhui Tapsell (Te Arawa, Tainui), and Frankie Stewart (Tangata Tiriti).

Important information
- It is important that everyone turns up on time for karakia
- At our discretion tickets are fully refundable or transferable
- For tikanga purposes beginner ticket sales close two days before wānanga giving us time to hauhake (harvest) for you
- If class numbers are too low, we may have to cancel (and will offer a refund or transfer) so please check your emails before class
- We offer concession tickets for students, unwaged, seniors, and those with disabilities.
- It is important to us that our classes are accessible to all. If ticket costs are a barrier for you please visit our website to enquire about our reduced cost or free tickets
- We welcome children aged 10-14 but they should be accompanied by an adult with a ticket

Follow us on Facebook or Instagram: Otari Raranga Weavers
For more information about what to expect and what to bring visit our www.otariraranga.co.nz

We mihi to our funders and sponsors Wellington City Council, Wellington Gardens and the Ōtari-Wilton Bush Kaitiaki, Maverick Creative, Good Fortune Coffee and Wellington Apothecary.

id: Visual Journalling - Drawing for Mindfulness-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Visual Journalling - Drawing for Mindfulness
venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
description:
Learn how to use drawing and mark-making for visual journalling, to draw out your inner guidance and resources, and bring a creative form of wellness into your daily life.

Lara Phillips, a creative facilitator trained in Interactive Drawing Therapy, will guide you through simple practices that open our subconscious; a resource we can all tap into, to help ourselves.

Note, this is not therapy or counselling rather a self-care tool that you can integrate alongside other wellbeing practices, such as journalling, walking or meditation.

No drawing skills required, this is more mark making not art making.

Each week combines a mix of guided drawings (where you follow cues), practices with others in the group, and self-guided drawings, using knowledge and tools you can take away.

Week 1: Ground
Learn what sits at the heart of this practice, and how to access your subconscious to draw out what it is you need.

Week 2: Wonder
Explore techniques with others in the group, to learn the power of open cues and different ways to listen to your inner voice.

Week 3: Play
Experiment with different ways of playing with your drawings, to stimulate the subconscious to guide you.

Week 4: Self
Apply your knowledge from the workshop to develop self-guiding skills to continue drawings at home.

What is provided: All necessary materials are provided. This includes A3 paper and coloured crayons, as well as printed resources with guiding cues.

What to bring: (Optional) Any preferred journalling materials of choice, such as large journals, coloured markers or coloured pencils. Feel free to bring an A3 folder/case/wallet.

Homework will be offered to help integrate the practice with your personal life.


Sundays, 11 am - 1 pm, 20 July - 10 August.

id: Shostakovich Unpacked | NZSQ + Antipodes Quartet-Prefab Hall, 14 Jessie St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Shostakovich Unpacked | NZSQ + Antipodes Quartet
venue: Prefab Hall, 14 Jessie St, Wellington
description:
Introducing Shostakovich: Unpacked. A four-part concert series presented by New Zealand String Quartet and friends to commemorate the 50th anniversary of Shostakovich’s death.
Across four night-time gatherings, the NZSQ will take to the stage with Orchestra Wellington, Antipodes Quartet, Ghost Trio, and pianist Jian Liu to explore the raw emotional power of one of the 20th century’s most troubled, yet defiant, musical voices.
Each concert features a specially curated selection of the chamber music of Shostakovich, paired with the unique voices of Aotearoa composers. From duets, to quartets, to a full chamber orchestra, we're getting up close to the celebrated chamber music and lasting legacy of Dimitri Shostakovich, 50 years after his death.
We invite you to join us on the journey of “Shostakovich: UNPACKED”, as together we explore and question what this powerful music meant in the time Shostakovich wrote it, but also how vitally important the composer’s artistic voice still is today.
Concert Two: Wednesday 6 August, 6:30pm, NZSQ x Antipodes Quartet
Artists onstage: NZSQ / Antipodes Quartet
Shostakovich: 6th and 7th String Quartets, String Octet
Unpacked: The music of Gao Ping
Spotlight: Be part of Aotearoa’s musical history, as the first chapter of the newly formed Antipodes Quartet unfolds in their Wellington debut. Created as part of a visionary new partnership between NZSQ, Chamber Music New Zealand, and the Adam Chamber Music Festival, the next generation of leading chamber musicians step forward; two string quartets artistically colliding, joining forces to perform Shostakovich’s gripping octet.
Tickets: $15 - $55, or get a season pass to all four concerts for $180 per person
Season pass discount will be automatically applied at checkout when you have one 'Season Pass' ticket per person, per concert date in your cart.
In order:
Wednesday 9 July, 6:30pm & 8:30pm, NZSQ + Orchestra Wellington
Wednesday 6 August, 6:30pm, NZSQ + Antipodes Quartet
Wednesday 1 October, 6:30pm, NZSQ + Ghost Trio
Tuesday 25 November, 6:30pm, NZSQ + Jian Liu

Time and date: 8pm Thursday 31 July 2025
Venue: The Circus Bar, 17b Allen St

Disclaimer: This is a comedy show. Any audience participation is 100% voluntary and consensual. No one will be forced into the Cuck Chair (unless they're really into that).

id: Ōtari Glow Worm Tour-Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush, 160 Wilton Road, Wilton, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Ōtari Glow Worm Tour
venue: Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush, 160 Wilton Road, Wilton, Wellington
description:
Take a guided night tour through Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush and discover some of the fascinating night-time residents on your way to see the titiwai/glowworms. Enjoy the tranquil beauty of the bush after dark and witness the magical glow of these unique creatures.

This outdoor night-time tour takes just over an hour.
If bringing children, we find it most suitable for those aged 5 years and older.
The tour requires a moderate level of fitness, the route includes numerous steps to and from the glowworms.

Meet at the Ōtari Visitors Centre, 150 Wilton Road. Bring warm clothes, walking shoes, and a torch.

This tour is operated by the Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush Trust. Join the Trust from just $20 a year and the glow worm tour is free, plus you’ll be supporting the amazing work the Trust does. Join today at owbt.nz/membership-donations/

Glow Worm Tour Ticket Refund Policy
• No Refunds: We do not offer refunds for Glow Worm Tour tickets.
• Ticket Transfers: If you can’t attend your booked tour, we will put you on a future tour, subject to availability. Please contact us as soon as possible to arrange this.
• Weather Conditions: Tours operate rain or shine. In the event of extreme weather or unsafe conditions, we will reschedule your tour or provide a refund.

For any changes or inquiries, please get in touch with us in advance at Treehouse@wcc.govt.nz or call 04 499 1400.
